Big zero 0/10Finally, I decided to write something about this book.I gave up reading this. It didn't work for me at all. Probably, I stand against the whole world, don't mean to do this, simply asking why? What is your problem?I did not understand this book or its positive rating. One or two stars are usually not for me, but I think there is no excuse for so much callousness, cruelty, and shocking violence.

I could write a one-sentence review of this book, saying that it features Beethoven, talking cats and obsessive love and that therefore I couldn't but love it. Or I could write another one-sentence review, stating that it's Murakami and that therefore it's inherently good and interesting. Both of these statements would be true and more or less complete, but all the same I think I'll go into slightly more detail.Kafka on the Shore is a story about a fifteen-year-old bookworm who calls himself Kafka (as you do) and runs away from home, partly to look for his lost mother and sister, but mostly to get away from his horrible father, whose crimes against him are never fully explained. Fate draws him to a town where, among other things, he meets two women who may well be his mother and sister, which doesn't prevent him from having sex with them. His story, which is as Oedipal as they come, is intersected with that of Nakata, a sixty-year-old simpleton who, among many other unique gifts, can talk to cats. It quickly transpires that Kafka's and Nakata's lives are interconnected, but exactly how this is doesn't become clear until the end, if indeed it does then.There is much to enjoy here. As always, Murakami's prose is supremely efficient; every sentence matters and takes you closer to the inevitable denouement. As always, the characters are tremendously likeable and off-beat. One could argue that they're not entirely three-dimensional, but who cares when they have such a story to tell? For theirs is quite a story. Like all of Murakami's 'weird' books, Kafka on the Shore is light on facts and heavy on metaphysical stuff. It's not a book for those who like straightforward stories; many of the questions raised are left unanswered, which I love but which will leave those who are of a slightly more literal bent unsatisfied. Nor is it a book for people who care about realism. What with its curses, entrances to other worlds, mackerel rainstorms, ghosts, concepts assuming human form and heavy emphasis on fate, destiny and reincarnation, Kafka on the Shore has a distinctly fairy-tale-like atmosphere, which is probably why I liked it so much (apart from it featuring Beethoven, talking cats and obsessive love, I mean). Parts of the story were clearly inspired by Japanese mythology. In its own turn, I can see this book being the inspiration for a very good Japanese movie. Maybe it has a little too much violence and incest in it to be turned into an anime film, but I can think of quite a few 'regular' Japanese directors who could do great things with this particular brand of mysterious magic realism. Which begs the question: how come the book hasn't been adapted to the screen yet?Anyhow, to cut a long story short (and to prevent this turning into a panegyric on Japanese cinema), I loved this book. If I'm not giving it five stars, that's because it lacks the emotional resonance of Norwegian Wood (my favourite Murakami book so far) and because Philip Gabriel's translation is a little too American for my taste. If I could give it four and a half stars, though, I would -- for the skilful way in which Murakami weaves together his two storylines, for his haunting descriptions of the power of memories and longing, for the many matter-of-fact weird touches he adds (Johnnie Walker and Colonel Sanders, anyone?), and, naturally, for his throwing in Beethoven, talking cats and obsessive love. It doesn't get any better than that, does it?

When the wind blows, the sea trembles like a shy, little girl. In a far distance, the crimson sun sets. You hear a piano piece playing over and over again. You are not sure if the music is in your head or a pair of expert hands are playing with your consciousness. Your hair dances and you close your eyes with the warmth, forgetting the woes that once defined you. And that's what Kafka On The Shore is, That's what it will ever be.I was drawn to this book for the mood that it presented. It opened my imagination and set my spirit spinning with possibilities and ideas. It's rare to find a story with this effect. The prose, as always by Murakami, it's charming, smooth, and intelligent without being pretentious. An amazing read.Murakami has concocted a contemporary blend of Oedipus and Orpheus, East and West, Freud and Jung, Hegel and Marx, Tales of Genji and Arabian Nights, Shinto and Buddhism, abstraction and action, alternating narratives and parallel worlds, seriousness and play, not to mention classical, jazz and pop music. He doesn't provide much detail but gives you irrefragable operative truths in his written work, the rational closure-seeking mind may not find a welcome place here.As I finish this review, Iâ€™m very excited. Yes, I know that Iâ€™ve got my memories to look back to, but what Iâ€™m excited about are those memories that havenâ€™t been made yet. The future is ahead of me, Iâ€™ve got time on my hands. The possibilities are endless.

At times reading this book felt like reading a water color painting the rippling language that connected the reality to the spiritual realm highlighted the connection of western literature (and pop culture) to life in a remote Japanese village. It did have a few WTF moments, well more than a few, actually you could argue this entire book was a what the fuck moment but the poetic language that came out, especially in the dialogue, created a truly profound impact on me as a reader. Whether it be the conversation of free will between Johnnie Walker and Nakata, fate between Hoshino and Colonel Sanders, Memories between Kafka and Miss Saeki, or gender and identity from the lips of Oshima, this work held a western filtered mirror to eastern life in a way that Joyce followed the Odyssey in Ulysses with a tidal wave of Oedipus.Actually Oedupus was the engine, because (SPOILER) Kafka was actively trying to pursue the prophecy, which is fascinating (and WTF) because I've never read a book before that had such a proactive protagonist pursuing such a non-heroic prophecy. Will I read more Murakami? Yes, but I think I need a fucking break and a fucking drink.

Sogni, realtÃ , gatti e musicaKafka sulla spiaggia Ã¨ un romanzo che si legge come lo si percepisce dal punto di vista dei personaggi: prendendosi il tempo necessario, senza forzare il ritmo, non tentando invano di capire ciÃ² che non puÃ² essere compreso o spiegato. La storia che Murakami racconta Ã¨ un limbo tra realtÃ  e immaginario, un po' come se il mondo dei sogni si catapultasse nella vita reale (o quello reale si catapultasse in quello dei sogni). Oppure, per usare le parole dell'autore, si viaggia verso i confini del mondo.L'introspezione Ã¨ profonda e delicata, e in piÃ¹ sono molto belli secondo me i passaggi dedicati alla percezione del tempo, alla solitudine (tema sempre ricorrente con Murakami) e alla musica, vista come strumento di salvazione dal vuoto interiore."Poesia e simbolismo sono sempre stati inseparabili. Come i pirati e il rum."

REREAD 20213/5starsWow, I think this is the first reread I've done where the book DROPPED in rating. I have always considered Kafka to be one of my favorite Murakami's, but to be completely honest, I really didn't enjoy my rereading experience. I'm not sure if it was because I personally was in a bad mental health space when i picked this up, or if it truly is just THAT different from what I remember, but this was definitely not what I was expecting to feel coming out of this reread.When first reading this book I liked, like with all Murakami books, how weird it was, how confused it made me feel, and how unique the story is. But, upon reread, I found this book extremely easy to read, mostly plot focused, and I found myself not caring or straight up hating characters and plot arcs. Kafka is insufferable, the incest and sex is honestly just too much, the entire Oedipus Rex retelling aspect of this book is just a big ole' "WHY" in my mind, I loved Nakata's parts up until it got far more boring in the middle sections, and the characters just didn't speak to me like they usually do. I didn't find it that weird or unique (maybe because I read it before? but also I've never felt that with a Murakami book - especially FIVE YEARS after reading it), I didn't find the whole mystery weirdness to it very difficult to figure out (but, I have gotten 3 degrees since first reading this book so maybe I just was able to read it and figure things out easier?) and overall there wasn't that Murakami charm I'm always so excited for. There was no spark to this book for me - again, it might be my mental health, so I'll definitely be returning to this book one day, but for this reread, I just simply wasn't impressed.FIRST READ 2016 4/5stars 3/31/16 Edit: I've decided to lower this to 4 stars and not put it on my favorites list. After sitting on it for a few days, this book was definitely excellent, but I simply didn't enjoy it as much as "Wind-Up Bird" or other 5star/favorite books! 5/5stars "Kafka on the Shore" was my third novel of Murakami's that I read, and this was probably even better than "The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle." Probably. And I LOVED "Wind-Up Bird", so this novel definitely lived up to my expectations from my love of that story. In this novel we follow a young 15 year old runaway who has renamed himself to Kafka Tamura, and an elderly, mentally retarded man named Nakata, whose lived inevitably intertwine - without them meeting each other. While Kafka is running away from his problems with his neglectful father, Nakata is trying to discover the answer to his own mysteries. Both have their own quirks - such as Kafka's illusion of the "boy named Crow" and how Nakata can speak to cats after falling into a mysterious coma when he was nine years old. This story shows the incredible stories of both of these characters and the complex way their lives parallel and affect each other. Along with many other characters who obviously affect the two of them.While "Wind-up Bird" was written like a dream, in an almost un-comprehensible way, where nearly nothing made sense, even in the end (which was personally one of my favorite parts - the mystery of the story) this book was just as complex, but made a LOT more sense. Although it left many questions in the end, it did wrap up in a much more understandable way."Kafka" still had the wonderful magical realism and postmodern themes, which is obviously why I loved it so muchLike I said, I might have liked this even more than "Wind-Up Bird," which is crazy because I've been OBSESSED with that book since I finished it - still thinking about it and running through it in my brain, STILL trying to figure out what on earth it was about. But this book still had the Murakami charm from "Wind-Up Bird" and it also made more sense. I honestly can't tell you right now which I liked more - because I liked them in very different ways. I enjoyed this in more of an actual story way, but the other book in more of a way where it has really affected me and my thinking of the world.And do I even need to mention the fact that every single character was WONDEFUL? Murakami is a genius when it comes to fleshing out characters and making the reader really connect with each and every one of them.Overall, this book was FABULOUS. It has all of that magical realism, postmodern, Murakami charm while still being a story that nearly every reader could follow.I highly recommend this as a first novel of Murakami. Like I said, you still get his charm, while reading a story that is still easiER to follow than some of his other novels. But, of course, like all Murakami novels, this is definitely not for younger readers. This has very explicit sexual content, graphic violence that rivals "Wind-Up Bird" and a lot of adult themes to it even though we are following a 15 year old boy, and honestly some parts of this story are EXTREMELY disturbing. Spoilers from here I LOVED Oshima! He was the first LGBTQIA character I have seen in a Murakami novel, and he was so badass, I honestly loved him and everything he did and stood for in this novel. Good job Murakami, good job, A+.The boy named Crow was a very interesting touch. I found myself reading for pages and pages and suddenly realizing I had been reading a very simple, normal story, and then suddenly the boy named Crow would pop up and remind you exactly why this book was magical realism. That "character" (if you can call the boy named Crow a character?) still left you with many questions at the end, but also made the story much more interesting, though I wish we'd gotten a little more of an explanation about him - but it's Murakami, so obviously I was a bit too hopeful.I also just REALLY want to know what exactly happened when all the children, including Nakata, fell unconscious. It was obviously a way to make Nakata the way he was, but I just really want to know exactly what happened, it's killing me not knowing!Okay, that scene though, with Johnnie Walker and the cats and the eating the hearts UCK, that was actually rivaling the scene in "Wind-Up Bird" with how disgusting. I actually felt sick after reading it. Murakami is King of writing absolutely disgusting descriptions that are still really pretty:"It all happened in an instant. The belly split wide open and reddish guts spilled out. The cat tried to scream but barely made any sound at all. His tongue, after all, was numb, and he could hardly open his mouth. But his eyes were contorted in terrible pain... A moment later blood gushed out, wetting Johnnie Walker's hands and running down his vest... Then, as if it were the most natural thing in the world, he popped the heart into his mouth and began chewing silently, leisurely savoring the taste." (page 144)This description goes on for several pages. Yum...And oh gosh, the cat from "Wind-Up Bird" made an appearance! I actually like audibly went "are you joking" while on a train and people stared at me. Oops:"A cat sauntering along stopped to watch, a skinny, brown-striped cat whose tail was slightly bent at the tip. A personable cat by the looks of it." (page 404)I also enjoyed some of the wonderful quotes from dialogue between characters there were. Here are some of my favorites:" 'Anyone who falls in love is searching for the missing pieces of themselves. So anyone who's in love gets sad when they think of their lover. It's like stepping back inside a room you have fond memories of, one you haven't seen in a long time. It's just a natural feeling.' " -Oshima (page 297)" 'It's not just that I'm dumb. Nakata's empty inside. I finally understand that. Nakata's like a library without a single book. It wasn't always like that. I used to have books inside me. For a long time I couldn't remember, but now I can. I used to be normal, just like everybody else. But something happened and I ended up like a container with nothing inside." - Nakata (page 306)" 'You have to be strong to survive... Nobody's going to help me. At least no one has up till now. So I have to make it on my own. I have to get stronger - like a stray crow. That's why I gave myself the name Kafka... Strength itself become your morality.' " - Kafka (page 316)" 'The most amazing thing of all has been you, Mr. Nakata. You canged my life. These past ten days, I don't know - things look different to me now. Stuff I never would've given a second glance before seems different... Nothing like this ever happened to me before. And it's all because of you. I've started seeing the world through your eyes.' " - Hoshino (page 407)" 'The world is a metaphor, Kafka Tamura. But for you and me this library alone is no metaphor. it's always just this library... It's a unique, special library. And nothing else can ever take its place.'" -Oshima (page 465) end of Spoilers

Kafka on the Shore is my first ever Haruki Murakami novel, and it certainly won't be the last. It was so much better than I'd expected; indeed I'd had no idea that I would encounter such a perplexing yet incredibly engaging story when I first decided to read it (I had to read a couple of articles after I was done to get things straight). Needless to say, I think Murakami is a bloody genius to be able to come up with all those convoluted metaphors and philosophical discussions; to present us with such memorable and unique characters; and to deliver it all in absorbing and beautiful prose.This is definitely a novel that I will be reading again someday, for it is one of those books in which you will always be able to unearth new interpretations, stumble upon fresh connections, and reach a deeper understanding of the very complex message contained within. It might all sound too abstract to those who have not read Kafka on the Shore yet, and rightly so, for you need to experience this world yourself. I don't think I would have understood much either if someone had tried to explain it for me prior to reading it myself. As a side note, I enjoyed Nakata's and Hoshino's chapters much more than Kafka's. Oshima and Sakura were extremely interesting as well.Trigger warning: RapeSome of the quotes that I liked: - I stare at this ceaseless, rushing crowd and imagine a time a hundred years from now. In a hundred years everybody here--me included--will have disappeared from the face of the earth and turned into ashes or dust. A weird thought, but everything in front of me starts to seem unreal, like a gust of wind could blow it all away. I spread my hands out in front of me and take a good hard look at them. What am I always so tense about? Why this desperate struggle just to survive?- Most things are forgotten over time. Even the war itself, the life-and-death struggle people went through, is now like something from the distant past. We're so caught up in our everyday lives that events of the past, like ancient stars that have burned out, are no longer in orbit around our minds. There are just too many things we have to think about every day, too many new things we have to learn. New styles, new information, new technology, new terminology... But still, no matter how much time passes, no matter what takes place in the interim, there are some things we can never assign to oblivion, memories we can never rub away. They remain with us forever, like a touchstone.- "You can't look too far ahead. Do that and you'll lose sight of what you're doing and stumble. I'm not saying you should focus solely on details right in front of you, mind you. You've got to look ahead a bit or else you'll bump into something. You've got to follow the proper order and at the same time keep an eye out for what's ahead. That's critical, no matter what you're doing."- "The strength I'm looking for isn't the kind where you win or lose. I'm not after a wall that'll repel power coming from outside. What I want is the kind of strength to be able to absorb that outside power, to stand up to it. The strength to quietly endure things--unfairness, misfortune, sadness, mistakes, misunderstandings." "That's got to be the most difficult strength of all to make your own." "I know...." - "Do you know why people have to do such cruel things like that to other people?" the tall soldier asks. "I have no idea," I reply. "Neither do I," he says. "I don't care who the enemy is--Chinese soldiers, Russians, Americans. I never wanted to rip open their guts. But that's the kind of world we lived in, and that's why we ran away. Don't get me wrong, the two of us weren't cowards. We were actually pretty good soldiers. We just couldn't put up with that rush to violence.- "What should I do?" I ask, staring at the ground in front of me. "You have to overcome the fear and anger inside you," the boy named Crow says. "Let a bright light shine in and melt the coldness in your heart. That's what being tough is all about. Do that and you really will be the toughest fifteen-year-old on the planet. You following me? There's still time. You can still get your self back. Use your head. Think about what you've got to do. You're no dunce. You should be able to figure it out."- "...But still, even for a short time, I'd like to be a normal Nakata. Up until now there was never anything in particular I wanted to do. I always did what people told me as best I could. Maybe that just became a habit. But now I want to go back to being normal. I want to be a Nakata with his own ideas, his own meaning."- There are a lot of things that aren't your fault. Or mine, either. Not the fault of prophecies, or curses, or DNA, or absurdity. Not the fault of Structuralism or the Third Industrial Revolution. We all die and disappear, but that's because the mechanism of the world itself is built on destruction and loss. Our lives are just shadows of that guiding principle. Say the wind blows. It can be a strong, violent wind or a gentle breeze. But eventually every kind of wind dies out and disappears. Wind doesn't have form. It's just a movement of air. You should listen carefully, and then you'll understand the metaphor."

Murakami and I have a history. His books were read less for interest than for a weird feeling of 'worthiness' (aka giant crush of mine at the time loved the guy), which soon turned to a puzzling at the weirdness already inherent. Puzzlement led to questioning, my library website led me to Goodreads, and I cannot say if I would be here without Norwegian Wood having wafted me along to some semblance of understanding. However, auspicious circumstances did not include auspicious receptions, and I left Murakami at three for three (stars) three years and counting hence, where he'd still likely be if he wasn't so effing popular.Someone out there may be disagreeing with me, but when you hang out for as long as I have in the middling <1,000 rating stacks, anything with healthy tens of thousands for more than five works is of monstrous proportions. Maybe the raving is clear to someone else, but even all the hipsters banding together the world over can't account for this pumping up of a surreal Japanese author with Eurocentric taste and atrocious abilities in erotica, especially on a site based in the US. Or maybe it can, and the population of said label has been bounding upwards faster than I thought possible. Or it's not just the hipsters. Hm.Going back to the previous category of readerly folk, how would I feel about that, if that were true? About the same as I feel about this book: interested, ticked off, and begrudgingly accepting only due to not being able to parse it as vivisectionally as I'd like. Ticked off states include misogyny, awkward name dropping, and flinging around that 'undefinable' state of authorial description to a suspiciously conscientiously evading blame extent, but. I can't get my finger on any of it, what with the rate of world turning dream turning every clear intent on its head. If I could, I'd be able to distract myself from all the piquancies that bloated up that up there rating to a healthy four, so congrats, Murakami, if that was your game.Except, who knows. I could be plastering my own abiding fixation on World War II all over the delicious hinting at violence, free will, and morality (dramaturgy's my new word of the day), but then again. I could reject the fascinatingly myriad complexities of character development due to awkwardness and lack of direction, but the jerks are possibly balanced out by the hazy sense of truth. I could sniff at the extended referencing that never quite colluded with the rest of the narrative flow, but whether that seeming obviousness was due to lack of skill or the overarching rudderless of tone is impossible to say. Then throw in the fact that this is a translation into the mix, and you have yourself a 'What? Uh. Sure? No. But. Agh.' of a time.What I know for sure is that I like cats, and libraries, and thinking talk, and most of all being engaged at every moment, for better or for worse. Even during the sex scenes, which, Murakami, for the love of everything worthwhile, I really hope you don't think the world of that particular aspect of your writing. Keep to all that other stuff about redemption and humanity and life and the joys of coffee shops, and we'll be okay.P.S. I know that it's April Fools Day. This is not a joke. This book fucked with my head enough as it is.

Tamura Kafka ha quindici anni, ma sembra molto piÃ¹ vecchio della sua etÃ . Cerca di sfuggire alla profezia, che al tempo stesso Ã¨ una maledizione, fattagli dal padre, che coincide con il mito di Edipo: Kafka ucciderÃ  il padre e giacerÃ  con la madre e la sorella. Per questo motivo, al compimento dei quindici anni, decide di abbandonare la casa del genitore, uomo con cui dice di non andare affatto dâ€™accordo e che per lui Ã¨ quasi un estraneo, al pari della madre, che lâ€™ha abbandonato quando aveva solo quattro anni, prendendo con sÃ© la sorella. [â€¦] ma anche se vai piÃ¹ lontano che puoi, non Ã¨ detto che riuscirai davvero a fuggire da qui. [â€¦] Il tempo grava su di te con il suo peso, come un antico sogno dai tanti significati. Tu continui a spostarti, tentando di venirne fuori. Forse non ce la farai, a fuggire dal tempo, nemmeno arrivando ai confini del mondo. Ma anche se il tuo sforzo Ã¨ destinato a fallire, devi spingerti fin laggiÃ¹. PerchÃ© ci sono cose che non si possono fare senza arrivare ai confini del mondo.Nakata Ã¨ un anziano che sembra un bambino. In seguito a un strano avvenimento accaduto durante una gita scolastica nei boschi durante la seconda Guerra Mondiale, Nakata perderÃ  la memoria, ma anche la capacitÃ  di leggere e scrivere. E imparo che un certo tipo di perfezione Ã¨ raggiungibile solo attraverso unâ€™infinita accumulazione di imperfezioni.I due sembrano destinati a incontrarsi, ma in realtÃ  non lo faranno mai, non direttamente almeno. Il loro mezzo di contatto indiretto sarÃ  la signora Saeki, direttrice della biblioteca privata dove Kafka si ritroverÃ  a passare le sue giornate dopo essere scappato di casa. Da giovane la signora Saeki ha fatto la cantante per un breve periodo, incidendo la canzone Kafka sulla spiaggia, che nel libro di Murakami Ã¨ anche il titolo di un quadro, oltre che il nome di uno dei due personaggi protagonisti. Sebbene sembri una donna equilibrata, la signora Saeki in realtÃ  Ã¨ profondamente infelice a causa della morte dellâ€™amore della sua vita avvenuta venticinque anni prima. Â«Anchâ€™io sognavo sempre di andare in un mondo a parte. Un posto al di fuori del tempo, dove nessuno avrebbe potuto raggiungermi.Â» Â«Ma un posto del genere non esiste.Â» Â«Infatti, non esiste. Per questo vivo cosÃ¬. In un mondo dove tutto si danneggia, il cuore si consuma, e il tempo scorre senza un attimo di tregua.Â» [â€¦] Tutti perdiamo continuamente tante cose importanti. Occasioni preziose, possibilitÃ , emozioni irripetibili. Vivere significa anche questo. Ma ognuno di noi nella propria testa â€“ sÃ¬, io immagino che sia nella testa â€“ ha una piccola stanza dove puÃ² conservare tutte queste cose in forma di ricordi. Un poâ€™ come le sale della biblioteca, con tanti scaffali. E per poterci orientare con sicurezza nel nostro spirito, dobbiamo tenere in ordine lâ€™archivio di quella stanza: continuare a redigere schede, fare pulizie, rinfrescare lâ€™aria, cambiare lâ€™acqua ai fiori. Nel caso di Nakata e della signora Saeki, il primo vive nel presente e non ha nessun ricordo; la seconda vive nel passato grazie ai ricordi che, oserei dire, per lei rappresentano quasi una maledizione perchÃ© le rammentano qualcosa che poteva essere, ma che non Ã¨ stato; entrambi perÃ² hanno metÃ  della loro ombra. Ma allo stesso tempo ti lacerano dentro.Molto interessante il personaggio di ÅŒshima, bibliotecario della biblioteca della signora Saeki che diventerÃ  per Kafka, oltre che un amico, un mentore e una guida. La particolaritÃ  del personaggio, se cosÃ¬ la vogliamo definire, Ã¨ una patologia che lo affligge, lâ€™emofilia, e il fatto che sia transgender. Donna che si sente uomo a tutti gli effetti. Ho sempre apprezzato ÅŒshima sia come personaggio in sÃ©, sia nel suo modo di parlare e di pensare. Sono stata completamente catturata dalla scena riguardante lui e le due signore che si dicono femministe: fin dallâ€™inizio mi sono vergognata per loro, e quando ÅŒshima le zittisce in modo cosÃ¬ elegante â€“ per di piÃ¹ in unâ€™uscita che proprio non mi aspettavo â€“ ho davvero gioito. Effettivamente io sono un poâ€™ diverso dagli altri. PerÃ² fondamentalmente sono un essere umano tra tanti esseri umani. Ãˆ questo che vorrei tu capissi. Non una creatura di un altro pianeta, ma un normale essere umano che sente e agisce come tutti. A volte perÃ² questa piccola differenza diventa per me una voragine senza fondo. Ma al fatto che questo accada periodicamente, sono ormai rassegnato. [â€¦] Gente priva di immaginazione, intollerante, senza orizzonti. Gente che vive una realtÃ  fatta di convinzioni tutte sue, slogan vuoti, ideali orecchiati qua e lÃ , sistemi rigidi. Sono queste le persone che a me fanno davvero paura. Le temo e le disprezzo. Naturalmente, anche capire ciÃ² che Ã¨ giusto e sbagliato Ã¨ importante. Ma nella maggior parte dei casi, ognuno col tempo puÃ² correggere i propri errori di valutazione. Se si ha il coraggio di riconoscere i propri errori, il piÃ¹ delle volte Ã¨ possibile rimediare. Ma la ristrettezza di vedute, la rigiditÃ  di chi Ã¨ privo di immaginazione ha una natura simile a quella dei parassiti. Si trasferiscono da un organismo allâ€™altro, mutano di forma e continuano a vivere e a proliferare. Sono casi senza speranza. Ma almeno qui vorrei che non mettessero piede.Kafka sulla spiaggia, come molti altri libri â€“ se non tutti â€“ dello scrittore giapponese, Ã¨ ricco di simbolismo e io, completamente inesperta, non sono sicuramente in grado di cogliere tutti i significati. Sono perÃ² andata subito a vedere che significato assume il corvo nella cultura giapponese. Consideriamo infatti che il primo capitolo si intitola Il ragazzo chiamato Corvo: scopriremo, nel corso della lettura, che il ragazzo chiamato Corvo Ã¨ una sorta di alter ego di Tamura Kafka e, come se questo non bastasse, in ceco Kafka significa proprio corvo. Il corvo in Giappone simboleggia lâ€™affetto famigliare; nella mitologia perÃ² i tengu, ovvero corvi con tratti antropomorfi, sono abili nel combattere, ma anche nel combinare guai; sono dispettosi, ma anche saggi, dispensatori di insegnamenti ed esperti nella trasformazione. Quasi tutte caratteristiche che nel bene o nel male appartengono al nostro Tamura Kafka. A che scopo faccio sempre tutti questi sforzi? PerchÃ© devo lottare cosÃ¬ disperatamente per vivere? [â€¦] Â«Tamura Kafka, nella vita câ€™Ã¨ un punto in cui non si puÃ² tornare indietro. E poi câ€™Ã¨ un punto, ma i casi sono molto piÃ¹ rari, in cui non Ã¨ possibile andare avanti. Quando questo accade, che sia un bene o un male, lâ€™unica cosa che possiamo fare Ã¨ accettarlo in silenzio. Ãˆ cosÃ¬ che viviamo.Interessante poi come i sensi di colpa di Kafka, convinto di aver ucciso il padre anche se logicamente Ã¨ impossibile, sono piÃ¹ forti della colpa in sÃ©, che lui non ha. A questo possiamo ricollegarci una frase che ritorna spesso nel romanzo, secondo cui la responsabilitÃ  comincia nei sogni. Trovo che sia una frase â€“ nonchÃ© un modo di pensare â€“ davvero molto bella, carica di significati, ma che mi trasmette anche tristezza e malinconia.Categorizzare i libri di Murakami, e Kafka sulla spiaggia non fa nessuna eccezione, Ã¨ quasi impossibile. Lâ€™autore mescola nei suoi romanzi generi diversi. Possiamo sicuramente ricondurre questa storia al realismo magico, dove sogno, realtÃ  e finzione si amalgamano tra loro. Nello stesso tempo perÃ² abbiamo la tragedia greca che si mescola con la tragedia famigliare; abbiamo un viaggio di formazione, ma anche un viaggio nel senso piÃ¹ letterale del termine; abbiamo addirittura scene horror e cronaca nera.E ancora una volta la musica diventa un aspetto quasi centrale del libro, essa stessa prende le parti di una protagonista. La musica, la melodia in particolare, viene usata da Murakami come mezzo di comunicazione, per noi lettori, e per i suoi stessi personaggi. Sembra quasi dotata di potere: riesce a calarci nellâ€™atmosfera, riesce a far cambiare modo di essere a un camionista dal passato di teppista, riesce a trasmettere emozioni. Non vi nego che ogni volta finisco per andare ad ascoltare le canzoni o le melodie che lo scrittore cita nei suoi libri. Il silenzio Ã¨ una cosa che si ascolta.Kafka sulla spiaggia mi Ã¨ piaciuto. Mi ha ricordato altri romanzi che ho letto dello scrittore, come Lâ€™assassinio del Commendatore o 1Q84. Non Ã¨ il mio preferito, ma anche in questo libro ho trovato frasi che hanno saputo toccare i tasti giusti. In generale credo che i libri di Murakami piacciano cosÃ¬ tanto perchÃ© danno la libertÃ  al lettore di interpretare la storia a seconda della propria vita, della propria esperienza, di quello che sta passando in quel dato momento o a seconda dello stato dâ€™animo in cui si trova nel momento in cui sta leggendo il libro. I suoi libri sono scritti in modo che ognuno di noi li possa sentire suoi. Ãˆ come se lo stesso scrittore si prendesse la briga di ascoltarci e di consolarci, di rassicurarci e tranquillizzarci. Questo almeno Ã¨ quello che provo io quando leggo un suo libro, non so se possa essere un sentimento comune. Qualche volta il destino assomiglia a una tempesta di sabbia che muta incessantemente la direzione del percorso. Per evitarlo cambi lâ€™andatura. E il vento cambia andatura, per seguirti meglio. Tu allora cambi di nuovo, e subito di nuovo il vento cambia per adattarsi al tuo passo. Questo si ripete infinite volte, come una danza sinistra col dio della morte prima dellâ€™alba. PerchÃ© quel vento non Ã¨ qualcosa che Ã¨ arrivato da lontano, indipendente da te. Ãˆ qualcosa che hai dentro. Quel vento sei tu. PerciÃ² lâ€™unica cosa che puoi fare Ã¨ entrarci, in quel vento, camminando dritto, e chiudendo forte gli occhi per non far entrare la sabbia. Attraversarlo, un passo dopo lâ€™altro. Non troverai sole nÃ© luna, nessuna direzione, e forse nemmeno il tempo. Soltanto una sabbia bianca, finissima, come fosse fatta di ossa polverizzate, che danza in alto nel cielo. Devi immaginare questa tempesta di sabbia. [â€¦] E naturalmente dovrai attraversarla, quella violenta tempesta di sabbia. Ãˆ una tempesta metafisica e simbolica. Ma per quanto metafisica e simbolica, lacera la carne come mille rasoi. Molte persone verseranno il loro sangue, e anche tu forse verserai il tuo. Sangue caldo e rosso. Che ti macchierÃ  le mani. Ãˆ il tuo sangue, e anche il sangue di altri. Poi, quando la tempesta sarÃ  finita, probabilmente non saprai neanche tu come hai fatto ad attraversarla e a uscirne vivo. Anzi, non sarai neanche sicuro se sia finita per davvero. Ma su un punto non câ€™Ã¨ dubbio. Ed Ã¨ che tu, uscito da quel vento, non sarai lo stesso che vi era entrato. SÃ¬, questo Ã¨ il significato di quella tempesta di sabbia.

Rather magical, sometimes confusing, but easy to read with lots of themes and byways to get lost in. There are also some serious points to ponder and questions to ask. I enjoyed the read and finished it yesterday; however reflection since has produced a few interesting thoughts.There are effectively two plots which intertwine and gradually move towards each other. Kafka Tamura is a 15 year old boy who lives with his distant and rather cruel father, his mother and sister having left when he was small; there is a strong oedipal theme in the book. He leaves home to find his own way in life. Nakata is a man in his 60s living on welfare. When he was a child he was part of an incident where a group of children on an outing all lost consciousness. He was the only one seriously affected; he cannot read or write and his abilities seem quite limited. He is able to talk to cats and they talk back to him. He feels he has a mission to accomplish, but is not sure what it is. Surreal forces lead Nakata; he finds a lost cat, is lead to kill a cat-killer (who may or may not have significance for Kafka), is able to predict/make things fall from the sky (try mackerel and leeches). Nakata knows he has to travel over a large bridge. He meets a lorry driver called Hoshino who latches onto him and helps him in his quest and they follow Nakataâ€™s instincts up to the end. Hoshinoâ€™s journey is interesting in itself as he discovers the joy of classical music and meets a Hegel quoting prostitute. He also meets a concept who takes the shape of Colonel Sanders.Meanwhile Kafka finds his way to the same city Nakata is headed for. He meets a girl who looks after him briefly (is he his sister? Possibly, possibly not) and finds his way to a library where he meets the rather distant Miss Saeki and the friendly Oshima. Kafka spends some time at Oshimaâ€™s cabin in the woods and begins to live and work in the library. Here he becomes obsessed with a late 1960s song called Kafka on the Shore and Miss Saeki as she was in her younger days (to explain would take over long). The whole thing comes together in a satisfactory and suitably magic way as the two stories converge. There is an awful lot going on; there are links with Japanese religious (particularly Shinto) traditions all wound together with the oedipal myth. The potency and power of music as a transformative medium; reality and dreams interrelate in interesting ways. There are, of course, lots of cats; though the torture scenes with the cats are a little stomach churning, but thankfully brief. The shadow of the war is present. There is, I think a tension between self-suffiency and interdependence; particularly in the relationships between Nakata and Hoshino and between Kafka and Oshima. I think the philosophy of Hegel is also important, especially the idea of thesis, antithesis and synthesis. I wonder whether the two strands of the story are thesis and antithesis with the synthesis at the end. Incidents and moments in the book also mirror the same type of movement and I suspect a second reading would illuminate this more: Murakami has said there are riddles in the book which become clearer when the book is read again.There are some questions I want to pose though. Hoshino and Kafka have remarkably good/mind-blowing/fulfilling sexual experiences; doesnâ€™t anyone ever have bad sex in Murakami novels? More seriously Kafka has sex with Miss Saeki who is in her early 50s (and who may or may not be his mother). He is 15 and this left me with an uncomfortable question. If we reversed the roles and Kafka was female and had sex with a man in his 50s, what sort of reaction would we have? That is a particularly pertinent point at the moment in Britain given the Saville and others investigations (It is worth noting that Rolf Harris has been charged with having a sexual relationship with a 15 year old girl when he was in his early 50s). Writers have to write about these things and in the context of the book nothing felt out of place given the magic realism going on. However, the question occurred to me, so Iâ€™m posing it. The novel is beautifully written, inventive, funny and magical and I enjoyed it as Iâ€™ve enjoyed all the other Murakami novels Iâ€™ve read.

This books is so good, strangely I felt connected somehow at many levels and with many characters at the same time!!! I usually read books related to science non fiction topics, so whenever I dare my self and take the opportunity to get out of my scientific comfort reading habitat and stumble onto books like these, it really blows my mind. This is my first Murakami experience and I confess I did not know what to expect or how I would feel about talking cats but yet, I was still intrigued. I went for this title because Im a huge fan of Kafka short stories, so obviously the title got my attention and wasn't disappointed. Surprisingly, the main character's favorite Kafka story is also one of my favorites "In the Penal Colony". A big plus for that!What did I like? Kafka on the shore begins slow, Murakami takes his time with the reader and gets him into the story with no hurries, he is not trying to impress you right away and I liked that. Slowly, the story develops and suddenly you got trapped by the author! Kafka on the Shore follows an Oedipal complex tragedy type of story. Kafka Tamura, the main character is a kid who was abandoned by his mother. So the story begins, with the young teenage kid getting both physically and mentally prepared to escape home and this Oedipal curse and go into a journey to look for his mother and his sister, as well as for himself, his identity. Kafka, not even his name but, like I said, of one of his favorite authors, was a lonely tough kid, a reader who would always hide at bookstores reading books like "A thousand and one nights". I also loved reading his dualistic nature represented through a boy named Crow, whom he uses to become a stronger kid under specific circumstances: "Sometimes fate is like a small sandstorm that keeps changing directions. You change direction but the sandstorm chases you. You turn again, but the storm adjusts. Over and over you play this out, like some ominous dance with death just before dawn Why? Because this storm isn't something that blew in from far away, something that has nothing to do with you. This storm is you. Something inside of you. So all you can do is give in to it, step right inside the storm, closing your eyes and plugging up your ears, so the sand doesn't get in, and walk through it, step by step. There's no sun there, no moon, no direction, no sense of time. Just fine white sand swirling up into the sky like pulverized bones. That's the kind of sandstorm you need to imagine".  As a parallel story, there is Nakata, an old man, who when he was a just boy lost consciousness during a school mushroom field trip along with other 15 children, but he was the only one who could never become himself again after a period of coma. He lost half of his "spirit", but while in search of it, he is somehow attracted towards Kafka's destination. Nakata, who always speaks in third person, lost his memory, his intelligence, his ability to read but acquired the ability to talk to cats and to predict bizarre events, becomes a professional finder of lost cats. How would the lives of Nakata and Kafka collide and what do the have to do with each other?  I also have to mention the cat killing scene... quite a chapter!!! So Shocking and powerful!! Metaphorical! I enjoyed it, but not because of any sadistic nature (huge animal lover here) but how this Johnnie Walker "the cat killer" man pushes Nakata to the extreme of taking a decision. Nakata has to choose to stand up and take the strength to kill the torturer or to remain a passive person who wont dare to take control of the situation and allow this man to continue torturing the animals in such a horrible way. Somehow, this chapter led my mind to: How many of us become "cat killers" and how many of us remain passive on many real life situations?. This are the kind of magical thinking Murakami gives you in here, a resemblance and application of "In the Penal Colony". Murakami's Kafka on the Shore is philosophical, surrealistic, sexual, full of mysticism, musical, subliminal, so.... "Kafkaesque"! Highly recommended for those who are looking for a unique or different reading experience.

I lost patience with Murakami a bit this year after reading the massively disappointing 1Q84. Compelling for about 700 pages 1Q84 suddenly began to read like something that was being made up as it went along and, worse, that the author had lost both inspiration and interest. Stripped down to its rudiments Kafka on the Shore can be read as an oedipal story. The son is wounded by his motherâ€™s abandonment of him and he blames his father. Covets a murderous hatred towards him. The novel is almost like the boy Kafka under a kind of Jungian/Freudian hypnosis. Dreams or myths become the healing place, archetypes/spirit doubles/art the healers. Kafka will never be able to resolve his identity crisis with his actual parents so he has to recreate them internally. Jung differentiated the ego and the self â€“ ego as consciousness, the entire scope of the psyche as self. So the promptings of Crow can be seen as self battling with Kafkaâ€™s limitations as purely ego. Ultimately itâ€™s easy to read Kafka as a kind of celebration of Jungian psychoanalysis. Which for me is where it falls down. Any novel written to verify a theory is going to appear forced at times and Kafka on the Shore, behind all its riddles and imaginative bravado, did often read to me, the story within the story aspect, like an entrenched treatise rather than a free flowing, pathfinding, moving story. There is of course a lot more going on. Most of Murakamiâ€™s familiar themes are present here. The cool teenage boy disenfranchised by his family and frequently engaging in idealised sex. Vulgar consumerism in the form of a character called Johnnie Walker, a serial killer of cats â€“ always emissaries of the spiritual world in Murakami. The ghost lover in the form of Miss Saeki, a woman who has never recovered from the death of her young lover and lives entirely in her memories. The shadowy shifting borders between the waking world and a kind of sorcererâ€™s dimension with always a guide or conduit that leads from one to the other. The loveable simpleton, in this case Nakata who is a cross between a benign version of the Erinyes in Greek Myth and a fairy godfather. This is another problem, the more you read Murakami, the more his novels blur into one another, the more, in fact, you get the sense that he is always to a large extent writing the same novel. Iâ€™ve now got to the point where I wish Murakami would write a very different kind of novel. Perhaps even a straightforward conventional one.

I'm trying to determine what was the exact point at which I knew that Kafka On The Shore was a 5-star diamond. Maybe it was when I was introduced to Nakata, an old man who could talk to cats (as in having conversations with them) and who later has an interaction with Johnnie Walker in the flesh? Or maybe it was when, through Oshima, Murakami gives a most humanly correct punch in the face of political correctness of hypocrisy in one of the most awesome chapters ever written? Or maybe it simply was when I realized that the only way to understand this book of riddles was to look within me. Yes, Kafka On The Shore is pure Murakami, which means that a bunch of things (ok, most things) seemingly make no sense whatsoever. Whether they'll like it or not, most people will say that too many things are left unexplained in the end. I beg to differ. It's not easy to put to words what I have in mind, so bear with me. Like what's the case with most of Murakami's novels, Kafka On The Shore is like an encrypted code which makes no sense unless the reader has the key which deciphers it. In this case, the reader is the key. Or rather, the key is in the reader. As you read, the code goes inside you, and depending on the key you bear, there's a different outcome. In short, the interpretation differs from person to person, but there's always one. Pretty much everything in the book is a symbol. Murakami spends a few pages in order to give the reader the heads up about what's to follow. Symbols, metaphors and abstract concepts are mentioned throughout the book and are the main ingredients which eventually will take the form of the vessel into which they are poured. The reader's psychology, that is. In other words, we're talking about a genius piece of literature which, even if you're not willing to put the effort needed to comprehend it completely, it will at least touch you in an abstract, impalpable manner that will have you wondering where it came from. The more I think of it, the more I come to conclude that in a deep, subconscious state of mind, where fish fall from the sky and cats talk with humans, I knew all along that 5 stars was the only way to rate this masterpiece.

I've be-reading this, in all its fabulous, virtuoso weirdness, in the hope of recapturing what I felt when it first came out. And yes, it stands scrutiny, but I've also changed: I still love Murakami's voice, but I find him less surprising, and I realize that I now find his portrayal of women in general increasingly problematic. I wonder if he sees that too: certainly an author has a right (and perhaps also a duty) to evolve beyond their initial perceptions of the world. I wonder whether this one will...

Sometimes reality is as strange as fiction. Stanger than even the most surreal fiction. When I came across this anecdote, it took me back to the dream-like you-gotta-be-kidding-me feeling evoked by Murakami in this book. For now, let this anecdote, as narrated by Mark Manson, stay here as a placeholder for a future review.In the closing months of 1944, after almost a decade of war, the tide was turning against Japan. Their economy was floundering, their military overstretched across half of Asia, and the territories they had won throughout the Pacific were now toppling like dominoes to U.S. forces. Defeat seemed inevitable.On December 26, 1944, Second Lieutenant Hiroo Onoda of the Japanese Imperial Army was deployed to the small island of Lubang in the Philippines. His orders were to slow the United Statesâ€™ progress as much as possible, to stand and fight at all costs, and to never surrender. Both he and his commander knew it was essentially a suicide mission.In February 1945, the Americans arrived on Lubang and took the island with overwhelming force. Within days, most of the Japanese soldiers had either surrendered or been killed, but Onoda and three of his men managed to hide in the jungle. From there, they began a guerrilla warfare campaign against the U.S. forces and the local population, attacking supply lines, shooting at stray soldiers, and interfering with the American forces in any way that they could.That August, half a year later, the United States dropped atomic bombs on the cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Japan surrendered, and the deadliest war in human history came to its dramatic conclusion.However, thousands of Japanese soldiers were still scattered among the Pacific isles, and most, like Onoda, were hiding in the jungle, unaware that the war was over. These holdouts continued to fight and pillage as they had before. This was a real problem for rebuilding eastern Asia after the war, and the governments agreed something must be done.The U.S. military, in conjunction with the Japanese government, dropped thousands of leaflets throughout the Pacific region, announcing that the war was over and it was time for everyone to go home. Onoda and his men, like many others, found and read these leaflets, but unlike most of the others, Onoda decided that they were fake, a trap set by the American forces to get the guerrilla fighters to show themselves. Onoda burned the leaflets, and he and his men stayed hidden and continued to fight.Five years went by. The leaflets had stopped, and most of the American forces had long since gone home. The local population on Lubang attempted to return to their normal lives of farming and fishing. Yet there were Hiroo Onoda and his merry men, still shooting at the farmers, burning their crops, stealing their livestock, and murdering locals who wandered too far into the jungle. The Philippine government then took to drawing up new flyers and spreading them out across the jungle. Come out, they said. The war is over. You lost.But these, too, were ignored.In 1952, the Japanese government made one final effort to draw the last remaining soldiers out of hiding throughout the Pacific. This time, letters and pictures from the missing soldiersâ€™ families were air-dropped, along with a personal note from the emperor himself. Once again, Onoda refused to believe that the information was real. Once again, he believed the airdrop to be a trick by the Americans. Once again, he and his men stood and continued to fight.Another few years went by and the Philippine locals, sick of being terrorized, finally armed themselves and began firing back. By 1959, one of Onodaâ€™s companions had surrendered, and another had been killed. Then, a decade later, Onodaâ€™s last companion, a man called Kozuka, was killed in a shootout with the local police while he was burning rice fieldsâ€”still waging war against the local population a full quarter-century after the end of World War II!Onoda, having now spent more than half of his life in the jungles of Lubang, was all alone.In 1972, the news of Kozukaâ€™s death reached Japan and caused a stir. The Japanese people thought the last of the soldiers from the war had come home years earlier. The Japanese media began to wonder: if Kozuka had still been on Lubang until 1972, then perhaps Onoda himself, the last known Japanese holdout from World War II, might still be alive as well. That year, both the Japanese and Philippine governments sent search parties to look for the enigmatic second lieutenant, now part myth, part hero, and part ghost.They found nothing.As the months progressed, the story of Lieutenant Onoda morphed into something of an urban legend in Japanâ€”the war hero who sounded too insane to actually exist. Many romanticized him. Others criticized him. Others thought he was the stuff of fairy tale, invented by those who still wanted to believe in a Japan that had disappeared long ago.It was around this time that a young man named Norio Suzuki first heard of Onoda. Suzuki was an adventurer, an explorer, and a bit of a hippie. Born after the war ended, he had dropped out of school and spent four years hitchhiking his way across Asia, the Middle East, and Africa, sleeping on park benches, in strangerâ€™s cars, in jail cells, and under the stars. He volunteered on farms for food, and donated blood to pay for places to stay. He was a free spirit, and perhaps a little bit nuts.In 1972, Suzuki needed another adventure. He had returned to Japan after his travels and found the strict cultural norms and social hierarchy to be stifling. He hated school. He couldnâ€™t hold down a job. He wanted to be back on the road, back on his own again.For Suzuki, the legend of Hiroo Onoda came as the answer to his problems. It was a new and worthy adventure for him to pursue. Suzuki believed that he would be the one who would find Onoda. Sure, search parties conducted by the Japanese, Philippine, and American governments had not been able to find Onoda; local police forces had been scavenging the jungle for almost thirty years with no luck; thousands of leaflets had met with no responseâ€”but fuck it, this deadbeat, college-dropout hippie was going to be the one to find him.Unarmed and untrained for any sort of reconnaissance or tactical warfare, Suzuki traveled to Lubang and began wandering around the jungle all by himself. His strategy: scream Onodaâ€™s name really loudly and tell him that the emperor was worried about him.He found Onoda in four days.Suzuki stayed with Onoda in the jungle for some time. Onoda had been alone by that point for over a year, and once found by Suzuki he welcomed the companionship and was desperate to learn what had been happening in the outside world from a Japanese source he could trust. The two men became sorta-kinda friends.Suzuki asked Onoda why he had stayed and continued to fight. Onoda said it was simple: he had been given the order to â€œnever surrender,â€ so he stayed. For nearly thirty years he had simply been following an order. Onoda then asked Suzuki why a â€œhippie boyâ€ like himself came looking for him. Suzuki said that heâ€™d left Japan in search of three things: â€œLieutenant Onoda, a panda bear, and the Abominable Snowman, in that order.â€The two men had been brought together under the most curious of circumstances: two well-intentioned adventurers chasing false visions of glory, like a real-life Japanese Don Quixote and Sancho Panza, stuck together in the damp recesses of a Philippine jungle, both imagining themselves heroes, despite both being alone with nothing, doing nothing. Onoda had already by then given up most of his life to a phantom war. Suzuki would give his up too. Having already found Hiroo Onoda and the panda bear, he would die a few years later in the Himalayas, still in search of the Abominable Snowman.Later in his life, Onoda said he regretted nothing. He claimed that he was proud of his choices and his time on Lubang. He said that it had been an honor to devote a sizable portion of his life in service to a nonexistent empire. Suzuki, had he survived, likely would have said something similar: that he was doing exactly what he was meant to do, that he regretted nothing.

Word Association: Random--Strange--Ethereal--Ennui--Obtuse--Juvenile--Fascinating--Obscure--Esoteric--MasculineI am reluctant to launch into full review mode for a book that I don't completely understand. This (based upon what I can grasp) is a coming of age novel that takes place primarily in the head of a 15 year old boy. Murakami is very ethereal and most of the novel is a rather dreamlike state. The reader has no concept of what is reality, if any of it was. This was my second Murakami book and I must say I find him fascinating. In his nonfiction, memoir-ish book What I Talk About When I Talk About Running he reveals himself to be very self aware, philosophical, oddly fixated, isolated, obsessed, spends much time in his own head, and extremely intelligent and observant. I can see all of those elements in this novel. Because of that exposure, this novel basically struck me as hyper-masculine and in the most masculine of ways both childlike and childish. The preoccupations with silly, inconsequential things. The irresistible sexual prowess of a 15 year old boy. The irresistible sexual prowess of an insubstantial, average truck driver. The lack of of understanding the female characters and motivations. The preoccupation with "not sex" of Nakata who spends much of the novel ruminating over the notion that he's never had sex and doesn't have desire. And the cats?!?! What was with Johnny Walker and Colonel Sanders?! The male-est of male role models even if they were meant to be tongue in cheek (I don't even have the slightest clue what Johnny Walker looks like, but am familiar with the notion that he is iconic when talking about Whiskey). Not that there is anything wrong with male oriented novels. By all means, bring on the heady, philosophical, meditations about masculinity rather than shoot outs, swords, car chases, fighter aircraft/spacecraft and war. Truth be told, I havenâ€™t read enough novels of this type.All in all this was an interesting romp into the (what I consider to be) largely uncharted world of males contemplating masculinity and themselves on a philosophical level. There is also a lot of humor injected in the oddest of places. I actually enjoyed it and I want to read more Murakami. Hmm a book pondering masculinity. I think the world needs to read more like that (which hopefully won't result in the eradication of felines from the earth in pursuit of the elusive cat soul flute).3.5 Stars rounded up to 4 because there is something about Murakamiâ€¦Listened to the audiobook. Sean Barret and Oliver Le Sueur were very good.PS: I am recognize that my comment about more novels about men contemplating masculinity reveals my very limited canon of books actually read. The only other novel that I've read that I found to be similar is Long Division by Kiese Laymon which was also quite weird and wonderful in very odd ways.

Pretext: 
Basically it's fun to review books that are equivocal, as they open up thoughts at a time. This one has mainly positive opinions, and is highly popular, still I'm writing for it proved ambiguous within myself.
#Read 1:
"Adventure must start from running away from home."- William BolithoSo I started the book. A not-too-special beginning. Followed by a not-too-extraordinary escape, (from looks of it)on veins on the previous quote. Enter Sakura.From the point onwards, throughout the entire story it felt like the precocious kid had escaped not because of the prophecy but because he wanted to discover his sexual self. Like a kid suffering just from drapetomania. For he tended to fulfill the prophecy rather than flee from it. He hadn't anything special about him as the people around him seemed to believe always. He had poor narration skills. And the kinky stuff was pretty disgusting. I didn't bother that much about the half with Nakata.I felt my money being wasted. An over-rated book. I will rate it 1 just to reduce overall rating.
#Reread 2:
"You can't run away from the truth, for the truth will find you."I wasn't ready to move on. So I picked it up while planning to spend a weekend at a village in the bush.I started paying an undivided attention to the other half of the story, i.e. the one with Nakata and tried to feel the connection between them. That part is undoubtedly better as Kafka didn't took up the job of narration. And come to think of it, Kafka's adventures were pretty interesting as long as you ignore it from his perspective and try to visualize all of it on your own. Also from the mid-part it felt more like he can't avoid the prophecy and would do better to face it. Well, the best part about the story undoubtedly is the application of magic realism. I had no clue I would ever encounter anyone who implements it as masterfully as Gabriel GarcÃ­a Marquez, but Murakami comes quite close in the league. And Kafka's story in the end does fit perfectly like a jigsaw puzzle you had been trying for long to solve, and you're glad that it's finally over.See, a good piece of literature( I think) isn't always some boneless fish, so you've got to be careful. For me Kafka on The Shore had too many bones in it, but in the end it tasted delicious. Also you've got to respect something that has the capability to prove dubious to you.

What happens when you mix Greek tragedy with mythological symbols and Kafkian vision in a postmodernist concoction? Why, a fascinating novel, definitely better than The Wind-up Bird Chronicle - and that was quite a book! A story that contemplates the tragedy of the human being existence governed by fate and interdiction, where to win is to lose and to revolt is to accept. Where the only possible solution is to retreat into the imaginary, while â€â€¦like a movie fadeout, the real world evaporates. I'm alone, inside the world of the story. My favourite feeling in the world.â€ And you can catch this feeling just from the beginning, looking at the various meanings of the title: Kafka the writer who forever drifts on the shore of the unreality in order to point out the absurdity of life, becomes Kafka, the hero, trampling on the shore of consciousness, together with his alter ego, the boy named Crow (by the way, kafka means crow in Czech - I didn't know that!) in order to make sense of (his) life. Keep in mind that Kafka on the shore is also the title of a song and the title of a painting - and here you go, syncretism of arts resolved in a powerful voice that tells the story of a world whose meaning does not burden the characters (who do what they have to do) or the reader (who reads what he wants to read) and its simplicity creates perfection and its perfection creates tragedy, since gods forbid to the mankind any glimpse at perfection. And the story goes as follows: Kafka Tamura leaves his father on his 15th birthday, to "live in a corner of a small library" and look for his mother and sister who left when he was four. On the bus that he takes for Takamatsu he meets a girl, Sakura, maybe his sister and in Komura Memorial Library, a woman, Miss Saeki, maybe his mother. Oshima, the library assistant, offers him a job and a room and tells him Miss Saeki's story: she had found her half (just as the Platonic myth of the androgyne says) when she was fourteen and lost him (he died) when, at twenty, she had just become famous by composing a song, Kafka on the Shore. Since then she has lived a dreamlike life, not really connecting with anyone. Sometimes her teenager self visits Kafkaâ€™s room at night to contemplate a picture on the wall, named Kafka on the Shore. Kafka becomes at the same time her son and her lost lover, falling in love with the girl and the woman; he has a brief sexual relationship with the woman, even if he suspects she could be his mother. This narrative plot is intertwined with another, the story of Satoru Nakata, who lost many of his intellectual faculties when, as a boy, was rendered unconscious after a mysterious flash of light in the sky. He cannot read or write but he can speak to cats, and may be interpreted as a part of Kafka's personality. Anyway, he restores the balance disturbed by Miss Saeki a long time ago, closing the door to the other world with the help of a truck driver named Hoshino. It is told that Greek tragedy sprang from the incapacity of the human being to abide by the three laws at the same time: the law of the family, the law of the gods and the law of the city â€“ following one of them led the hero to infringe another. And here is Miss Saeki, who breaks at least two of the three: like a Greek heroin, she upsets the gods by aspiring to eternal love, and the family by abandoning her child; her punishment is to be condemned to exist forever in limbo, in life and death. Her redemption, however, is to save Kafka from the same fate, urging him to come back from no manâ€™s land with her legacy: â€œIf you remember me, then I don't care if everyone else forgets.â€On the other hand, Kafka is a (post)modern Oedipus, cursed to commit parricide and incest; but, unlike Oedipus, he doesn't try to escape his fate; he embraces it with a sort of hard and resigned understanding. He kills his father with his ambiguous hate and his mother with his ambiguous love, the blood of the first marking him, while the blood of the second will finally save him, His destiny has already been written and he cannot do anything against it, as Oshima (whose role seems to be similar to the Greek choir) points out: â€œListen, Kafka. What youâ€™re experiencing now is the motif of many Greek tragedies. Man doesnâ€™t choose fate. Fate chooses man. Thatâ€™s the basic worldview of Greek drama. The sense of tragedy - according to Aristotle - comes, ironically enough, not from the protagonist's weak points but from his good qualities. Do you know what I'm getting at? People are drawn deeper into tragedy not by their defects but by their virtues."And Kafka's destiny seems to be drawn like a Moebius band: his time and space are often upside down and he moves between past and present, between here and there, with admirable flippancy: â€œEven chance meetings are the result of karmaâ€¦ Things in life are fated by our previous lives. That even in the smallest events thereâ€™s no such thing as coincidence.â€The library is, of course, a major key, a place where all the important encounters take place, since it is there where all heroes' paths cross and all the knots are untied. It is also a metaphor of the inner being: â€œ...inside our heads - at least that's where I imagine it - there's a little room where we store those memories. A room like the stacks in this library. And to understand the workings of our own heart we have to keep on making new reference cards. We have to dust things off every once in awhile, let in fresh air, change the water in the flower vases. In other words, you'll live forever in your own private library.â€ Finally, there is the cat symbolism (a resumption from The Wind-up Bird Chronicle), which in Japanese culture means â€œgood fortuneâ€. Hence Nakataâ€™s gift, lost the moment he is forced to commit murder and inherited by his successor when order is re-established and evil defeated.According to Murakami himself: "Kafka on the Shore contains several riddles, but there aren't any solutions provided. Instead, several of these riddles combine, and through their interaction the possibility of a solution takes shape. And the form this solution takes will be different for each reader. To put it another way, the riddles function as part of the solution. It's hard to explain, but that's the kind of novel I set out to write" And since it is the readerâ€™s privilege to interpret them as he sees fit, this is the kind of solution I set out to give. â˜º

I love this as I loved his "Wild Sheep Chase" and "The Wind-up Bird Chronicles". While aversion to this author's absurdity is understandable, I find his works so far to be delightful and deep journeys that blend a mystery tale, coming of age themes, and ironic magical realism that approaches a new mythology. Our hero here is a self-reliant 15-year old boy who runs away from his Tokyo home under the assumed name of Kafka Tamura and holes up in a private library to read and find himself. He soon gets a job at the library. Special characters who intersect his life in a fateful way include an "intersex" girl passing as a boy, a woman who lives only in the past (because of lost love), and a man who lives only in the present (because of a mysterious X-Files type of event as a child). The latter is unable to read, but can talk to cats and make fish rain from the sky. Murakami can slip such bizarreness past the reader as just another course in his delicious meal, while constantly adding spices from literature, music, and philosophy. Sexuality plays a big role in this story, as is an integration and revision of the myths of Oedipus and of Orpheus. One character, a sensitive truck driver recruited for a quest of the illiterate character, is regaled by a prostitute philosophy major with a line from Bergson: "The pure present is an ungraspable advance of the past devouring the future. In truth, all sensation is already memory. Later a Colonel Sanders lookalike exhorts him: A life without revelation is no life at all. What you need to do is move from reason that observes to reason that acts. Despite the intellectual tidbits, Murikami succeeds well in making the reader care about Kafka and root for him in his compelling quest which relates to the disppearance of his mother when he was four. At the same time, the reader knows the author is playing and can take some comfort in the ride down the pathways of metaphor that keep leading back to ancient Greek dramas, about which we get instructed has the basic worldview that "Man doesn't choose fate. Fate chooses man."

Der ruhige ErzÃ¤hlton und die hervorragende Sprache von Ursula GrÃ¤fe lieÃŸen ein schÃ¶nes Leseerlebnis erwarten. Wenn diese Person, die permanent in der dritten Person Ã¼ber sich spricht, dann auch noch auf Johnny Walker sowie dem KFC-Maskottchen Col. Sanders trifft und zu einem Roadtrip Richtung Kafka aufbricht, beginnt es turbulent zu werden. Als dann Johnny Walker Katzen aufschlitzt, deren Herzen verspeist, von Nakata getÃ¶tet wird und spÃ¤ter Col. Sanders dem Chauffeur von Nakata eine Sexbombe vermittelt, die Hegel zitierend ihrem Kunden den besten Blowjob des Lebens liefert, wÃ¤hrend Kafka vielleicht seinen Vater ermordet und vielleicht mit seiner Mutter schlÃ¤ft und eventuell seine Schwester vergewaltigt, begann eine Phase im meinem Leseerlebnis, die sich mit der grundlegenden Frage beschÃ¤ftigte, ob ich fÃ¼r japanischen magischen Realismus gemischt mit einer Ã–dipus-Story und den alten Sexphantasien eines fernÃ¶stlichen Autors mit fragwÃ¼rdigem Frauenbild wirklich der richtige Leser bin. ***1/2Brimming with bewildering imagination and creativity, Murakami's Kafka on the Shore was certainly never a bore: with a multi-layered story, an array of wacky and wonderful characters, and his now trademark of including a large dollop of western culture references. For all it's weirdness, Murakami's narrative is still suffused with a great sense of melancholy and loss. I could even see traces of Holden Caulfield from The Catcher in the Rye in the character of Kafka Tamura, in regards his mistrust of adult lies about life, that stay in his tender consciousness. Tamura wants to escape from this fate but, in his dreams, of course, he is drawn towards it. The fun and drama of Murakami's storytelling is that you are never quite certain where those dreams end and where reality begins, and I found that to be Murakami's greatest forte here. The book I couldn't stop thing about for days, and at the time of reading, I'd simply read nothing else like it. There was so much lingering in my mind. I was disappointed with the ending, and the sexual content felt completely out of place, but it's still a novel I think of often, even though it's not my fave Murakami.

Beautiful prose, dreamy magical realism, haunting unresolved mysteries, and a fair dose of eloquent talking cats makes Kafka on the Shore an interesting read to say the least! Even though there's moments that made me uncomfortable and even though the ending left me wanting just a little bit more of a resolution, I would still say this book is a new favorite of mine. Kafka & Nakata were such compelling characters to read, and the way their narratives entwined was fantastic. This was my very first Murakami book but I will definitely be reading more. ~Will be making a video review on my channel at some point~
