[may contain slight spoilers]My second succesful foray into Murakami opus. After the weirdness of Hard Boiled Wonderland, I thought Kafka was quite tame in the beginning. Sure, there's some Twilight Zone incident with school kids at the end of World War II and a mysterious "boy named Crow" but for almost half of the book this read like a standard angsty teenager running away from home. Superbly written of course, but what's all the buzz surrounding this book?Oh wait: talking cats ! cute ... quirky ... I'm heading into Do'Des Ka Den territory. I couldn't have been more wrong. A couple of chapters later I went into weirdness overdrive with claw out my eyes out bloody horror scenes, leeches raining down from clear skies, hookers quoting Hegel and Western cultural icons giving lessons in Buddhism.Murakami doesn't like his reader to get too comfortable in his armchair and loves to throw a spanner in the works, throwing a linear storyline out of kilter and into uncharted territory - strange landscapes of the subconscious. Still, his violence, overt sexuality and general queerness is never gratuitous. Each supernatural incident has a role in pushing the story forward, and even if by the end some of the weird things will be left unexplained, enough keys to decode the metaphors are provided in the text. Like this line from Chekhov about the rules of dramaturgy : If a pistol appears in a story, eventually its got to be fired  .The whole world is a metaphor in Kafka on the Shore, the author deftly weaving into the narrative the curse of Oedipus, the fable of Hansel and Gretel, Orpheus descending into the land of the dead and much more. Placing most of the action in and around a library is a device used by many authors, probably because it permits deconstructing the surface story and go to the essence, extracting meaning from events and conflicts. It also allows the author to introduce tangential topics like feminism or gay pride, war or consumerism.In a way similar to Hard Boiled Wonderland, the book is structured in two parralel streams, apparently unrelated, developing independently but constanly converging towards a final confrontation / revelation / epiphany that seems predetermined from the start of the book - either by Fate, the Gods or the inability of the human actor to break free of the pattern.Kafka Tamura : "the toughest fifteen year old on the planet" , is the quintessential teenager on the edge of the precipice. Will he be able to leave the nest of family, school and social ties that has ruled his life so far? Will he soar free, self reliant and responsible for his actions or will he crash to the ground under the burden of insecurity, betrayals and loneliness? He is constantly trying to build up his physical body with daily exercises and to flex his neurons with all the books that fall in his hands. In one of my favorite quotes from the book, the answer is to be found inside himself: The strength Iâ€™m looking for isnâ€™t the kind where you win or lose. Iâ€™m not after a wall thatâ€™ll repel power coming from outside. What I want is the kind of strength to be able to absorb that outside power, to stand up to it. The strength to quietly endure thingsâ€”unfairness, misfortune, sadness, mistakes, misunderstandings Nakata is the protagonist of the second storyline. He's old and poor, he's not very smart, but he has his heart in the right place. An accident in his youth leaves him an "empty vessel" , unable to read or to find a job. He is the one character that reminded me of Kurosawa and his beautiful people living at the outskirts of civilized life. His misfortune has not made him bitter, he is helping his neigbors find stray cats, and his greatest joy is to eat eel from time to time. Fate, in the form of a Johnny Walker alter ego pushes him out of his familiar territory and onto a journey of self discovery and redemption. Along the way, he strucks a friendship with another "hollow" man - a truck driver drifting through life without aim or reason.The two stories, one of a youth at the start of his independent life, and one of an old man man trying to recapture his youth, dance around one another to a soundtrack switching between Schubert, Haydn or Beethoven, and John Coltrane, Prince or The Beatles towards a haunting pop song written by a young girl in love. There's also a well chosen reference to Francois Truffaut masterpiece "Les quatrecent coups" . A better hidden reference points to Jim Morrison and his open doors of perception. You'll know it when you come across it : "Come on baby, light my fire!"Another recurring theme I have identified after only two books, is the revelation of the meaning of life, to be found sitting at the edge of the ocean, in full summer sunshine, eventually with some scattered fluffly white clouds.For all these Western cultural references, Kafka on the shore is at heart a Japanese book. I was lucky to have read recently Kwaidan by Lafcadio Hearn, so I could pick up the source of the traditional ghost stories used as inspiration and foundation for this novel. Murakami offers further reading material suggestions in the text with his references to Ueda Akinari - Tales of Moonlight and Rain and to the novels of Natsume Soseki. I plan to read them, too.A few words about the humor : it's there to be found in the text, and provide a welcome breather from the deeper and darker main themes. Ranging from the absurd conversations with Colonel Sanders of KFC fame, to sarcastic felines or earthy jokes hinting at the best way to lose 5 pounds, the humor serves to illustrate the full range of Murakami abilities. Sometimes the joking is serious : Listen, every objectâ€™s in flux. The Earth, time, concepts, love, life, faith, justice, evilâ€”theyâ€™re all fluid and in transition. They donâ€™t stay in one form or in one place forever. The whole universe is like some big FedEx box. I could go on with my musings, but really, I'm not worthy. Go read the original.

I wish I could say I enjoyed this more than I did. I don't seem to have read anything I've really liked for weeks now, and I hoped this would break the pattern; the plot sounded appealing, I have a liking for magical realism, and having been intrigued by the hype surrounding Murakami's latest book 1Q84, I thought this earlier novel - which seems to be both very popular and very highly rated on Goodreads - would be a good introduction to the author. I read this over Christmas, and haven't been taking notes or drafting a review, so I can't really give the usual in-depth assessment of it, but here's a summary anyway...It started well, with chapters alternating between two protagonists - 'Kafka', a fifteen-year-old boy who has run away from home to escape an Oedipal prophecy made by his father, and Nakata, an elderly simpleton who can talk to cats and seems to possess other mystical powers. There were elements I really liked - the humour, the mystery, the touches of magic (talking cats that know everything!) and the promise of a complex and interlinked series of fantastical events. So far, so intriguing, but unfortunately I just didn't feel the book ever delivered on that early promise. It explored a lot of issues and theories surrounding philosophy, the power of thought, etc etc, but seemed to have a tendency to touch on these briefly, give a summary of some concept or other (often rather artificially forced into the dialogue) and then move on. Although I thought the sex scenes were actually pretty good, I couldn't help but be a bit disturbed by the context of them (the age gap on its own was pretty weird even without the possibility of Miss Saeki being Kafka's mother). Much of what happened was obviously supposed to be metaphorical, but the blurring of the lines between metaphor, dreams and reality meant I just ended up not really knowing what the story was trying to say. I found Kafka on the Shore interesting and readable, but by the end, I couldn't help but feel that a lot of what I'd spent all that time reading had been completely pointless. There's so much exposition, so many lengthy descriptions of the minutiae of life, so many diversions into characters' histories; not that this has to be a bad thing, but I kind of assumed it was all going to be FOR something, yet hardly any of it had anything to do with the crux and/or climax of the story. I found Murakami's style interesting enough that I DO want to read more by the author, despite the low rating I've given this book. Not so enthusiastic about picking up the epic 1Q84 now, however.

This was my second Murakami and was picked up after much hesistation and mulling over. I was maybe not ready to be hit with something so intense.Kafka on the shore proved to be so impacting and forceful, I lapped up at words and structure of the theme of the book. Murakami had me tight in the folds of his perceptual writing and I couldn't help feeling the weirdness of the characters spread over me. It is not wrong to say that I never wanted the book to be finished and wanted to know the characters of Nakata, Oshima and Hiroshi like I know my skin. I particularly loved the words of wisdom passed by Oshima to Tamura. Having read this, I am definately picking up another Murakami for a a deep dive into the space of emptiness and fullfillment.

~ Imperfection ~Why is it henceâ€” some people are always drawn towards imperfections; broken, shoddy, raw, downtrodden, messyâ€¦ all constitute beauty for their Imperfection-seeking eyes. Ergo imperfect people, imperfect surroundings, imperfect livesâ€¦ carry a certain undiscovered charm for a selected few, glossed over by the usual crowd. Isn't Imperfection the hallmark of beauty, after all! Imperfection beauty; Beauty imperfection.Isn't nature itself imperfectly perfect in its propensity! Little by little, glued together in a canvas, these imperfections create a perfect expanse of art. I would patently choose an imperfect life, imperfect man and imperfect book any day over the vast sea of seemingly perfect dwellers unconscious of their imperfections, blinded by obvious perfections satiating their pride.The pertaining metaphysical fiction slowly grows on you and is undoubtedly an acquired taste, earthily elite in its entirety. Thus, the highly flawed and imperfect reviewâ€” analogous to the book and the author it praisesâ€” retains Murakami's beauty and attraction. Consequently, a feeling was reached regarding this book; an imperfect accumulation of events, resulting in an imperfect piece of art, imperfectly executed, imperfectly read and imperfectly reviewed. Murakami, shrouded in his imperfect art, will always stand unique to this flawed being for evoking magic lurking in mundane and ordinary, cradling tenderness amid bizarre, and all in all its mysteries, bringing one a surreal reading experience.Inside the pages of Kafka on the ShoreInitially, to outset with the obvious, Murakami's commendable usage of classical Greek literature and mythology. Foremost, as perceptible, the book is a modern take on Oedipus Rex by 
Sophocles
, as debated in the book by the author's mouthpiece Oshima (if one has read the original Greek tragedy, one could discern many parallel characters). The ensuing classical theme Murikami employs is Aristophanes' response taken from Plato's Symposium. Aristophanes' speech delineates how man was split in half by Zeus and now looking for the other missing half; similarly, the characters are searching for their missing selves. Finally, Cassandra's curse is propounded. (This introvert will suppress her geek mode here and avoid going into mythological details).Moving on, Murakami unhurriedly builds his characters and situationsâ€” slowly shrouds them in metaphors before reaching the climax. It is not a simple tale but layered; in order to fully grasp it, one must take a Kierkegaardian 'Leap of faith' to plunge into this metaphorical journey with the author in the land of magical realism and beyond, blurring the boundaries of conscious and unconsciousâ€” a land where the former and the latter have no distinct demarcations. Nonetheless, the tale is simple at heart, carrying the weight of the human psyche. Inside emotional traumas collapsing with the external adversaries, sometimes resolving themselves, others complicatingâ€” while always preset there, never diminishing entirely or killing one eternally. One faces a limbo of forever mental and emotional labyrinth in the name of what they call 'Life'. 
"But thing in the past are like plate that's shattered to pieces. You can never put it back together like it was, right?"
Furthering to psychoanalytical realms...Aren't we all fighting some psychological battles, leaping roots back to our first memories and hence a never-ending labyrinth extending and shrinking, never vanishing, a beast with a life of his own. Ain't it, each man on the face of earth bearing a scarred child in the womb of his psyche, hiding from the vicious grasping eyes of the world, perpetually flawed and shattered, nonetheless nourishing its sustenance, till last breaths. Deathâ€” the real liberator!Oh manâ€” your eternal love,misery, your forever sweetheart, the tantalising past!The ramblings must be halted; hence one must surmise that all of the little 
Freud
 and 
Lacan
 this humble learner read could be applied here and more. By the time the story reached the climax, this being was so high on Murakami and his metaphors that Kafka Tamura was I and I Kafkaâ€¦ (how could I've found common ground with a 15-year boy, well, isn't this where literature stands, finding pieces of yourself). Conclusively, if the sole duty of the author was to craft relatable existential angst for the readers, then Murakami excelled in it and captured the youth at will.Finally, in all his obscurity, Murakami is a didactic man; as propagated, there is no saving but acceptance, one has to accept, and none will be their rescuer. Alternatively, maybe she is overreaching, but readers, let her, as the most depressing situations sometimes, somewhere hide the most sanguine alternatives, a silver liningâ€” as for every hell, there must be heaven.

A captivating and intriguing story intertwining the lives of a troubled teenage runaway with a man who converses with cats. SUMMARY Kafka Tamura is a troubled 15-year-old boy, who runs away to escape his sinister father and to search for his long-missing mother and sister. Shortly after Kafka runs away his father is murdered. Kafka wakes up hundreds of miles away to find himself covered in blood. He finds refuge in a small, private library in a town by the sea where he spends his time reading and contemplating his life and his future. He assists and is assisted by two librarians, the welcoming Oshima and the the remote Miss Saeki in becoming â€œthe toughest 15-year-old in the world.â€Satoru Nakata, is an aging simple man, who has never fully recovered from a childhood incident. This mysterious incident caused him to lose all his memories, as well as his ability to read and write, but he gained the ability to communicate with cats. This skill earns him a little extra money when he is occasionally hired to find his neighbors missing pets. It is in his search for Goma the cat, that Nakata encounters Johnnie Walker, a cat soul-stealer and things donâ€™t go so well between these two men. Nakata is later befriended by a truck driver, Hoshino who takes him on as a passenger. Hoshino become very fond of the old man who reminds him of his grandfather. Nakata and Oshinoâ€™s ride turns into quite an adventure. â€œIt's not just that I'm dumb. Nakata's empty inside. I finally understand that. Nakata's like a library without a single book. It wasn't always like that. I used to have books inside me. For a long time I couldn't remember, but now I can. I used to be normal, just like everybody else. But something happened and I ended up like a container with nothing inside.â€ REVIEWWhat an intriguing book that is both imaginative and inventive! The book raises more questions than it answers, which is precisely what makes it so intriguing. Author Haruki Murakami says the key to understanding this book is to read it several times. I have only read it once so canâ€™t claim to understand it but I certainly enjoyed it. There is so much to appreciate in this book with references to pop culture, magical realism. alternate reality, mystery and humor. The writing is lyrical, captivating and engaging. My absolute favorite part of the book was Nakataâ€™s character. His manner of speaking was charming and his conversation with cats was just amusing. Overall, Kafka on the Shore is a complex, riddle filled, delightful read. â€œClosing your eyes isn't going to change anything. Nothing's going to disappear just because you can't see what's going on. In fact, things will even be worse the next time you open your eyes. That's the kind of world we live in. Keep your eyes wide open. Only a coward closes his eyes. Closing your eyes and plugging up your ears won't make time stand still.â€ Publisher 	Random House AudioPublished 	August 6, 2013Narrator	 SeÃ¡n Barrett, Oliver Le SueurReview	 www.bluestockingreviews.com

Found lots of interesting lines and quotes from this book on goodreads.Was very keen to read this book.But when I found it,the initial impression was not too great.Seemed to lack a coherent story.I tried to read a bit more,but I couldn't.The writing style just didn't grab my attention and it is pretty lengthy too.Maybe it's great on metaphysical stuff but I was too bored to continue.Magical realism has never been my thing anyway.Abandoned,but the quotes are good.

I would never understand the underlying meaning of all the mystical overtones Murakami weaves throughout the book. Maybe it is never meant to make sense. In the midst of all the heavy magical realism I was left starving for meaning throughout the read hunting down for symbolisms, allegories that would tie this all together petering out in a anticipatory satisfaction. But it never did. It disappointingly goes along with characters' whims with no end in sight.But it built an innocuous frustration brewing in the aftermath. A frustration that pulled me from a lull, a lethargic limbo of dormancy. A dormancy I currently find difficult to get myself out of. But this dormancy is beautiful and so is the frustration it is was being sourced from. Not once in the book I felt like abandoning and starting off with something new. It is something I donâ€™t understand but wonder about at the same time. I wonder if this can be termed as appreciation or a mere inkling of confusion.Murakami builds these characters carefully in spite what his careless logic would fool you into something else. This I guess is my new venture into the unexplored realms of magical realism. It is those intricately woven situations which come out to be brazen and absurdly sticking out with heavy visualizations. As for the intelligent references, Oedipus complex, the prophecy and the yin-yang polarities between the characters are something which donâ€™t stand out in a way to hinder the flow of the mesmerizing fantasy.Murakamiâ€™s work are termed as simple but profoundly complex. Complex I believe is not the complex bit and pieces tied together building up towards a bravado that blows you away in a temporary ecstasy. It is the never ending journey of myriad of emotions, of twisted logic, a tantalizing absurdity that leaves a bit of it with you and stays. It is inexplicable yet unavoidable.Itâ€™s like the bursting of vivacious firecrackers into the dark quite sky in the night of harmless sadness. This vivacity is probably a testimony to our unresolved urge of bending the rules of logic and reason. It is not meant to make sense in the short term.Come to think of it, this is a celebration of madness that resides in our subconscious. What may seem to be vacuous on surface, an intelligence resides in the choices made by the characters. The freedom they chose to explore, the choices they are free to exploit is something any reader trying to satisfy the temptation of getting out of touch with reality would relate to.

â€œThereâ€™s a chance something strange might happen.â€â€œAre you kidding me? Everythingâ€™s been strange enough already.â€This was my second Murakami, and though it didnâ€™t delight me quite as much as The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle, which I read earlier in the year, I still loved it. Again we have screwy World War II history, playfulness regarding time and memory, dreams and other alternative states of being, cats in peril, and quite a bit of sex. But here myth and symbol take on greater significance. Thereâ€™s an Oedipal prophecy over 15-year-old Kafka Tamuraâ€™s life, and doubles/substitutes and portals to other worlds also play a major role. Kafka takes refuge in a library, where he is taken under the androgynous Oshimaâ€™s wing. Meanwhile, Nakata, a simpleton who finds lost cats and can communicate with them (â€œStrangely enough, with cats he never ran out of things to talk aboutâ€), has gotten caught up in a dark situation he doesnâ€™t understand, and sets off on his own journey. Kafkaâ€™s first-person chapters alternate with third-person chapters about Nakata, which makes you eager to keep reading and get back to each story. I canâ€™t pretend to get everything that goes on here, especially how Nakata and Miss Saeki are connected and what exactly the Boy Named Crow is supposed to signify. I also thought the last 60 pages or so were rather sluggish, and Hoshinoâ€™s slang was annoying. But I love diving into Murakamiâ€™s strange fictional worlds, and itâ€™s great knowing I have so much of his back catalogue to discover next year.

You know how sometimes you're reading a book and you think "God, this is weird and not great" but you're already like halfway through so you've invested far too much of your time in this to just give up on it? So you trudge on, hoping against hope that it gets better. Well... this book just doesn't get better. So if you're in the first 100 pages and you're thinking, "boy, this is getting strange in a weirdly uncomfortable way," I suggest you just stop reading and save yourself the trouble.So here are the parts of the book that literally just did not need to exist: HALF THE BOOK (maybe more)But let's get a little bit more specific. There were a couple of scenes in the book that were just so beyond unnecessary that I don't even understand. (TW for rape and sexual abuse I guess) 1. The scene in the library where Oshima tells off the "feminists." I get that the entire thing was obviously there so that Kafka could find out about Oshima's gender orientation (what is Oshima's gender orientation? Is he transgender? Because he refers to himself as a man and then calls himself sexless, and a gay woman. What. And then everybody else describes him as all of these things too) but it was so beyond unnecessary and was absolutely the scene where I knew that I would absolutely NOT enjoy this book. 2. Every sex scene. I mean, other than the fact that they were all super incest-y and rape-y and downright weird, they were just not good sex scenes (Why did every woman want to drink semen? Women don't want that. STOP.) The first sex scene with Kafka and Ms. Saeki was well, not a sex scene, it was a rape scene because she was sleep walking and he thinks "maybe I should stop her" but then doesn't because he's a horny 15 year old apparently. Cool. Then there was the dream rape-scene with Sakura a.k.a his sister. And that wasn't bad enough but dream-Sakura says "hey, you're raping me but it's okay as long as you can accept that we won't see each other again." Um, okay. Great. None of this is fucked up at all.Then there was the scene with Hoshino and the prostitute when he's trying to find the entrance stone that literally had zero purpose. Why was that there? WHY? Also the letter that the primary school teacher writes near the beginning about how she hit Nakata before all the kids fainted. And she went into explicit detail about her sex dream with her husband and how turned on she was for the entire day. Again... WHY?3. Mr. Nakata's backstory. I mean, I get it, he was the person who was taking care of the entrance stone and he had to kill Kafka's dad because Kafka left but the whole fainting thing was never explained, neither was the half a shadow thing. It was just stuff thrown in there to say "whoah, look how weird!" Considering the whole fainting thing is what got me interested in the book to begin with, I was very, VERY disappointed.After finishing the book, I also have a LOT of questions because literally nothing was answered and absolutely nothing made sense. - Was the entire book supposed to be a reference to some Greek mythology full of incest? Because all I know about Oedipus is really from studying a bit of Freud and reading Hamlet. - Why did Kafka's dad prophesize weird incestuous things about him? Nothing about this made any sense whatsoever. - How is Ms. Saeki Kafka's mother and Sakura his sister when he is also Ms. Saeki's dead lover?- Why did the Colonel Sanders character need to exist? (alternatively, why did Murakami use a load of random characters that were basically all-knowing omniscient in order to explain away the lack of motivations of every single character in this book?) - Why did Kafka always think about women being related to him just before jacking off/sleeping with them... while running away from him dad because he didn't want to fulfill an incest prophesy? Did he not see the irony? Does nobody see the irony?- What was the entire point of the fish and eel raining from the sky other than to say "hey, this book is really weird and quirky and strange things happen"? - What was the point of Johnnie Walker? Why did we need to read a scene about him torturing cats? - Was Crow just Kafka's weird alter-ego who was also in reality a crow? etc etc. The list of questions are probably endless because the book did such a poor job of explaining anything. Murakami is also a pretty sloppy writer a lot of the time. He has passage after passage, describing very banal things (in a very banal way) that contributes nothing to the story. His prose isn't bad but it's not great either. Basically, unless you're a fan of incest, rape, bad sex scenes and having absolutely nothing explained, then I would suggest that you don't pick up this book.

Let's all be honest with ourselves. Murakami never writes anything remotely tame, so always expect mind-fuckery from his books. Even Norwegian Wood which is his most "normal" story with a chronological story line, has its "what in the ever living fuck did I just read?" moments. So if I had a mere 10 seconds to describe this book, I'd say it's Oedipus meets Flowers for Algernon with plenty of unsolved questions by the end. Sound weird? It really is.light spoilers aheadWe follow 15-year-old Kafta Tamura whose father has prophesied a dark nightmare where he will kill his father and sleep with his mother and sister. So he runs away from home and eventually ends up working at a library far from home. His father is murdered, but he has an alibi, but he still wakes up with blood on his shirt after blacking out. He also meets Miss Saeki, the woman who runs the library. He has a strong suspicion that she is his mother but also sees her 15 year old ghost in his room at night, which begs the question - do living people have ghosts? Obviously he develops a bit of an Oedipus complex with Miss Saeki. Things get weird from there but I'll let you explore it yourself.Our other main character is Mr Nakata, a man who became mentally disabled after falling unconscious along with other children in his class during WWII. He was the only one who did not wake up, and when he did, he knew nothing of the world, his family or himself. But he get a bonus - he can talk to cats. And he tracks down cats for a living. more light spoilersThere's a lot of philosophy in this book which is focused on more than the actual story. The conversations between characters is what really made me slurp up this book. The writing is beautifully translated and I wish I knew Japanese just to experience Murakami in all his glory. some men talk with stones, and some sleep with other menWhat I really wasn't expected was Oshima, a wonderfully represented gay trans man who works at Ms Saeki's library. Him being trans is stated once or twice, its not the focus of its character but you can see how it has shaped him. He's the most articulate and thoughtful of all the characters and he's the kind of diversity we need. I was pleasantly surprised since I don't see trans characters very often in Japanese media of any kind. If we reverse the outer shell and the essence - in other words, consider the outer shell the essence and the essence only the shell - our lives might be a whole lot easier to understandAny who, you expect Mr Nakata and Kafta to meet, but it goes it a totally different direction I didn't expect. The ending was open-ended, which I'm not a fan of but it is about the journey of a 15 year old so it makes sense that he has his whole life paved in front of him.I'd recommend this to fans of his other work, but not as a starting point for someone who wants to start reading his work. It's not very newbie friendly.And you really will have to make it through that violent, metaphysical, symbolic storm. No matter how metaphysical or symbolic it might be, make no mistake about it: it will cut through flesh like a thousand razor blades. People will bleed there, and you will bleed too. Hot, red blood. You'll catch that blood in your hands, your own blood and the blood of others. And once the storm is over you won't remember how you made it through, how you managed to survive. You won't even be sure, in fact, whether the storm is really over. But one thing is certain. When you come out of the storm you won't be the same person who walked in. That's what the storm's all about.

Cabe decir que esta novela tiene el toque de fantasÃ­a perfecto, nos deja muchos enigmas y nos ofrece una perspectiva Ãºnica acerca de la vida y la muerte.

Algo que tambiÃ©n me ha gustado mucho es el estilo narrativo del autor, surrealista y a la vez tan natural, sin ningÃºn tabÃº. Haruki Murakami utiliza muchas referencias musicales y literarias, las cuales nos permiten conocer y conectar mejor con los personajes. A mÃ­, particularmente, me encantaron. Cada vez que mencionaba una canciÃ³n que no conocÃ­a, la buscaba y la escuchaba; siento que, de alguna extraÃ±a manera, una entabla simpatÃ­a con el autor.AdemÃ¡s de mitologÃ­a y mÃºsica, a travÃ©s de los libros de  Murakami tambiÃ©n podemos apreciar mÃ¡s acerca de la simbÃ³lica e interesante cultura Japonesa. "Sometimes fate is like a small sandstorm that keeps changing direction.â€I wish fate has taken a direction towards Murakami soon in my life. Although, better late than never. Haruki Murakami is a name that has earned its place in the literature world with full dignity. I have read many authors to date ( though still feels like I just started) but Murakami has such a vivid imagination that while reading him, you will find your imagination floating into a whole unforeseen universe, something that you know cannot exist but it feels like it does. A man name Nakata can talk to cats and knows there exist an entrance stone that opens up to a parallel universe. Then there is a boy named Kafka ( toughest fifteen-year-old) who runs away from his home just to avoid the prophecy declared by his father but ends up being following it. Also, keep in mind that- Kafka talks to crow and his father kills cats to steal their souls for making a flute that carries harmonious music.So now you can imagine how creative Murakamiâ€™s stories can be. I loved each character and felt an instant connection with them. Not for once did I feel that the story is becoming dull or slow. It was a story that challenges your vision and makes you visualize things that might not have come to your imagination by itself ever. Also, the lessons that you can learn are worth reckoning."From my own experience, when someone is trying very hard to get something, they don't. And when they're running away from something as hard as they can, it usually catches up with them, I'm generalising, of course."I will surely recommend this to everyone who has an equally powerful imagination as that of Murakami. Besides, I am also very open to anyoneâ€™s recommendation of any other masterpiece by Haruki Murakami.

My second Murakamiâ€¦ I didnâ€™t hate it but was not impressed either: more perfectly slim girls, questionable sex scenes, primal fantasies and fabricated narratives, all marked by a fetishistic vibe. These seem to be fixed, integral parts of his protagonistsâ€™ psycho-sexual journeysâ€”essentially heterosexual, in this case, since Oshima seems to beâ€¦ lacking, a companion bound to be left behind in Kafkaâ€™s maturity.Although a little on the nose, the conversations with Oshima were by far the most interesting aspect of the novel. The foreshadowing and halfshadowing of Nakataâ€™s storyline began to bore me halfway through and kept waiting for it to intersect with that of Kafka. I was hoping to get a more thought-provoking take on childhood trauma and fatalism in fiction rather than the over-used oedipal complex and chance discoveries that conveniently, clumsily move the plot forward.

Kafka on the Shore is my second Murakami book. While I didn't like it as much as the first one I read, I still enjoyed it. How to describe it? Bizarre, magical, disturbing, thought-provoking, most definitely not predictable, and like nothing else I've ever read. Nakata - the simpleton who talks to cats was my favorite character. I loved his chapters more than Kafka's. I donâ€™t know if I will ever fully grasp the meaning of his books, but I will keep trying. 3.5 stars rounded up.TW for any animal lovers - just skip the Johnnie Walker chapter. I skipped it and had no trouble following along afterwards.

H. Murakami personifies metaphors and lets his characters enact the literal Oedipus play, and then calls it a metaphor too while throwing in Hegelian wholeness and some dream Inceptions in a surreal eerie world with talking cats and mackerel rains, all of which leading to an unresolved yet satisfying tale. I seriously appreciate, but can't think very high of it, i.e., 3.5 in goodreads terminology.

Mr Murakami, I'm delighted that I found my way back to your writing. I hadn't intended a re-read, and indeed I had forgotten that I had read this novel, (itâ€™s not your writing, but my failing memory!) but as soon as I started reading I remembered, and I simply could not put the book down.Where does one start reviewing a novel that offers so much? It brims with Greek mythology, Japanese and Western literature, Western music, and it explores several ideas.The chapters of the novel alternate (more or less) between the parallel stories of fifteen year old runaway Kafka (a name he chooses for himself) Tamura, and of an old man, Nakata. Each one has a quest. Each one acquires a helper. Kafka receives help and advice from the librarian Oshima who works at a magnificent private library. Nakata accepts a lift from Hoshino,, a commercial truck driver, who continues to assist Nakata. In addition, Kafka creates for himself an alter ego called Crow, whom he consults when confronted with a problem or a question. In fact, we learn that Kafka means crow in Czech. Crow constantly affirms: â€â€œRemember, youâ€™re supposed to be the toughest 15-year-old on the planet.â€â€ And so begin the connections, because besides the obvious connection to Franz Kafka the author, there is also a connection to a painting and a song titled Kafka on the Shore, as well as many other connections. Nakata, on the other hand, had an unusual experience as a child which has left him, in his own words, â€œdumbâ€ and â€œemptyâ€. However, he has the remarkable ability of being able to talk to cats, as well as causing various incongruous items to rain from the sky. He even talks to a stoneâ€¦Rather than discussing the plot, Iâ€™ll focus on a few random aspects that delighted me - there are far too many to discuss here.Kafka & OshimaAt the library mentioned above, Kafka and Oshima discuss the books that Kafka spends his days reading. Kafka, having finished reading The Arabian Nights, tackles the complete works of Natsume Soseki. This leads to a discussion of The Miner vs Sanshiro, and on a later occasion they talk about Schubertâ€™s Sonata in D Major which is then compared to the books just mentioned. And Kafka listens over and over to the song Kafka on the Shoreâ€¦Nakata & HoshinoLater, whilst Nakata is sleeping, Hoshino drinks coffee in a coffee shop where the owner plays a CD of Beethovenâ€™s Archduke Trio. â€œHoshino closed his eyes, breathing in quietly, and listened to the intertwining of strings and piano. Heâ€™d hardly ever listened to classical music before, but it was soothing and put him in an introspective mood.â€ Hoshino knows nothing about classical music, but he starts asking questions, and before long the owner tells him about the current performance (Rubinstein, Heifetz and Feuermann) as well as other famous interpretations such as the Oistrach Trioâ€™s version. The proprietor also explains how it came about that the piece was written, and Hoshino becomes so entranced that eventually he even reads a biography of Beethoven. â€œAnd now look at me, he thought, Iâ€™m into Beethoven â€“ can you believe it? A pretty amazing development.â€ Hoshino again visits the coffee shop, and on this occasion â€Something with stringed instruments was playing on the stereo. â€œHaydnâ€™s first cello concerto. Pierre Fournierâ€™s playing the solo,â€ the owner explained as he brought over his coffee.â€ So naturally a discussion of composer Haydn and performer Fournier follows. And Mr Murakami doesnâ€™t confine himself to classical music; there are bits about jazz, the Beatles, etc. Not surprisingly, one of the ideas probed in the novel is the transformative power of music. Kafka and Oshimaâ€™s conversation about Schubertâ€™s Sonata in D Major leads to a discussion of the perfection of imperfection. Elsewhere the following ideas (amongst many others) are explored:what is boring and what isnâ€™tappreciation and acceptance of those who are different to usintolerance and people without imaginationwhat would induce a kind, peace loving person to kill another?does resposibility begin with the imagination?can nothingness increase?fate - does man choose fate, or does fate choose man?the origin and nature of labyrinthsetc.Kafkaâ€™s discovery of the forest also enchanted me. There is mystery and inherent danger, but there is the wonder of stars and silence or birdsong. The forest also serves as a metaphor for what Kafka needs to experience in order to mature and reach the next stage of his life.And there I thought that Iâ€™m the only one who talks to cats - not so! Only in this novel the cats talk back, albeit only to a very select audience. But then cats are very discriminating by nature. Discover for yourself some delightful cat conversations. So yes, I havenâ€™t even scratched the surface of what is in this novel, but the above is a sampler of tidbits that appealed to me. #####Quotes: (not in chronological order)â€œThe library was like a second home. Or maybe more like a real home than the place I lived in.â€â€œWhen I open them, most of the books have the smell of an earlier time leaking out from between their pages â€“ a special odour of the knowledge and emotions that for ages have been calmly resting between the covers.â€â€œCompared to those faceless hordes of people rushing through the train station, these crazy, preposterous stories of a thousand years ago are, at least to me, much more real. How thatâ€™s possible, I donâ€™t know. Itâ€™s pretty weird.â€â€œI like to linger over each sentence, enjoying the style. If I donâ€™t enjoy the writing, I stop.â€â€œâ€˜A life without once reading Hamlet is like a life spent in a coal mine.â€™â€â€œBut still, no matter how much time passes, no matter what takes place in the interim, there are some things we can never assign to oblivion, memories we can never rub away. They remain with us for ever, like a touchstone.â€â€œâ€œMemories warm you up from the inside. But they also tear you apart.â€â€â€œI trudge along. Iâ€™m walking by the shores of consciousness. Waves of consciousness roll in, roll out, leave some writing, and just as quickly new waves roll in and erase it. I try to quickly read whatâ€™s written there, between one wave and the next, but itâ€™s hard. Before I can read it the next waveâ€™s washed it away. All thatâ€™s left are puzzling fragments.â€â€œAll these millions of stars looking down on me, and Iâ€™ve never given them more than a passing thought before. Not only the stars â€“ how many other things havenâ€™t I noticed in the world, things I know nothing about? I suddenly feel helpless, completely powerless.â€â€œMy head was completely empty, like a bathtub after you pull the plug.â€â€œSilence, I discover, is something you can actually hear.â€â€œThe stone was â€“ not unexpectedly â€“ speechless.â€â€œThe stone maintained its stony silence.â€â€œâ€œDo you think music has the power to change people? As though you listen to a piece and go through some major change inside?â€ Oshima nodded. â€œSure, that can happen. We have an experience â€“l ike a chemical reaction â€“ that transforms something inside us. When we examine ourselves later on, we discover that all the standards weâ€™ve lived by have shot up another notch and the worldâ€™s opened up in unexpected ways. Yes, Iâ€™ve had that experience. Not often, but it has happened. Itâ€™s like falling in love.â€â€â€œâ€â€¦ A dense, artistic imperfection stimulates your consciousness, keeps you alert. If I listen to some utterly perfect performance of an utterly perfect piece while Iâ€™m driving, I might want to close my eyes and die right then and there. But listening to the D major, I can feel the limits of what humans are capable of â€“ that a certain type of perfection can only be realised through a limitless accumulation of the imperfect. And personally, I find that encouraging. Do you see what Iâ€™m getting at?â€â€â€œPeople soon get tired of things that arenâ€™t boring, but not of what is boring. Whatâ€™s that all about. For me, I might have the leisure to be bored, but not to grow tired of something. Most people canâ€™t distinguish between the two.â€â€œHaving an object that symbolises freedom might make a person happier than actually getting the freedom it represents.â€â€œAll that was visible was the rear of the building next door. A shabby, miserable sort of building. The kind where shabby people spent one shabby day after another doing their shabby work. The kind of fallen-from-grace sort of building you find in any city, the kind which Charles Dickens could spend ten pages describing.â€â€œNakata had met many cats up till this point, but never before one who listened to opera and knew models of cars.â€â€œNakata stored this information away in his head, carefully folding it all away in a front drawer so he wouldnâ€™t forget it.â€â€œâ€œListen, every objectâ€™s in flux. The earth, time, concepts, love, life, faith, justice, evil â€“ theyâ€™re all fluid and in transition. They donâ€™t stay in one form or in one place for ever. The whole universe is like some big FedEx box.â€â€#####Perfect for Murakami addicts like myself!

Once upon a time lived in Theben a young man called Oedipus.As most young men at that time â€“ and nowadays too â€“ he had a father and a mother. When he was just a baby it was predicted that he was destined to one day kill his father and marry his mother. Even in ancient Greece such behavior was frowned upon â€“ but on the other hand you donÂ´t just kill a son of royal blood to prevent disaster.As fate would it, because fate is a very important ingredient in folklore, the boy lived and went on to fulfill the prophecy.Murakami builds a very long and complicated tale with basis in the tale of Oedipus Rex.There are some other elements as well; coming-of-age, sexual identity, road tripping, finding piece of mind, classical music, coming to terms with your mortality etc. etc. and a lot of sphinxes in the forms of cats and a weight-changing stone.Johnny Walker and Colonel Sanders plays important roles as well, though not in a way you would have anticipated Ooooh my freaking Goodness. There is too much of everything crammed into the 615 pages of my edition.Not that the storyline doesnÂ´t hold or canÂ´t be followed without going back and forth and nothing Murakami produces is not technically well written, but â€¦I just fail to see the purpose. Even if we agree that this is a case of â€œThe Journey, not the Destinationâ€ and I do appreciate the journey in the company of the characters it is a road to nowhere.

Itâ€™s my third time of reading this novel and again I cried at the end. I, too, have read about how people describe it as fantastical, metaphysical, gripping, but incomprehensible and inconclusive. Yes, itâ€™s a book in which humans talk with cats, fish and leeches fall from the sky, and soldiers missing in action from the time of World War II reappear alive and well. I recognize that the Greek myths of Oedipus and even Orpheus are key players and that there is a whole discussion of metaphor within its pages. Like when Kafka suggests, â€œThereâ€™re a lot of odd things going onâ€”but I feel like Iâ€™m slowly getting closer to the truth.â€ And Miss Saeki asks, â€œActually getting closer to a metaphorical truth? Or metaphorically getting closer to an actual truth?Every page is a mysterious path to go down, but I believe it should be read as a young boy leaving home and fighting with his own demons. Follow that path, and you will see everything else as potentially shedding light on that battle. You, too, might even cry at its conclusion

Ø¹Ù„ÙŠÙ‡ Ø£Ù† ÙŠØ·Ø±Ø­ Ø§Ù„Ø£Ø³Ø¦Ù„Ø© ÙˆÙŠØ«ÙŠØ± Ø§Ù„ØªØ³Ø§Ø¤Ù„Ø§Øª ÙˆÙŠØ­Ø±Ùƒ Ø§Ù„ÙØ¶ÙˆÙ„ .. ÙˆÙ…ÙˆØ±Ø§ÙƒØ§Ù…ÙŠ ÙŠÙØ¹Ù„ Ø°Ù„Ùƒ Ø¨Ø£ÙØ¶Ù„ Ø·Ø±ÙŠÙ‚Ø© Ù…Ù…ÙƒÙ†Ø©.

The feeling I have after the last page was turned over is akin to what I would have felt after taking a plunge into a rather cold and deceptively deep pool of water. The surface appears calm and the bottom of the lake appears within sight before you take the leap but this changes once you are in the water. There are areas which have pristine and divinely rich water, areas where the muck oozes into the pool and also garbage floating on the surface at other places. Murakami is at my first observation, a shaft of light that lights up the nooks and crannies in the attic of the human mind.A quest, that is is what the story is all about. There are two people going about this quest and in two glaringly different ways but in the end it all ties together. On the one side of the path we see Kafka Tomura, a 15 year old runaway with an Oedipus complex and a completely befuddled state of mind. The other side of the quest is Mr. Nakata, a polite-to-a-fault sexagenarian who can converse with cats and finds lost cats for aggrieved pet owners !Kafka goes through a process of growing up which while being painful, finally puts him at the threshold of a world better than the one he tried to run away from. Mr.Nakata while appearing to be a simpleton has more to him than meets the eye. I must say that the traits this character embodies are the ones that can evoke sympathy in many a reader. There are areas where in the naivete of the character worked on me as well. Other than the principal characters, my interest was perked by the character of Oshima who unlike many people in the real world knows the right thing to say at the right time. Plus, he talks philosophy while driving a Mazda Miata at top speed on a mountain road with Schubert's sonata as a backdrop. Interesting sort of chap !There are two locales that I fell in love with in the book. One is the Komura memorial library. Deep,spacious, filled with light and choke full of books this would have been a wonderful place to spend days lost in the grasp of books. The second and the more seductive of the two is the mountain cottage of Kochi where Kafka spends a few days. Imagine a log cabin hidden deep in the mountains where you can cook and eat your meals. All around you is the forest and the mountains. There is no electricity and no mobile phone to disturb your reverie. It has shelves crammed with books. Well,now I have a fair idea of how I should spend my post retirement days !Well so much for the good things. There are parts in the book that make no sense or adds no value to the path which we walk. There is a particularly graphic chapter which to me was pretty much an avoidable one. Not that violence affects me but it feels out of place in a book like this. There are a lot of loose threads that dangle and shift in the breezes even after I finished the book which is not a very satisfying thing. There is a lot of power in Murakami's writing. As you go on reading, you can feel the trapdoors in your mind open to let in the light for maybe the first time & at the same time many a passage will make you feel the windows of your mind bolt shut to keep the wind out. The book is like a song that does not touch you at first but starts growing on you each time you revisit it.

Just finished this book about 10 minutes and have that post Murakamifeeling of what do I do now!!!This book was just so unusual and captivating and beautifully writtenthat it's difficult to know what to read next.Murakami's books are very easy to read but you need to be prepared for something very unique and just go with the flow.Even though the story is very different to anything else I have read andthe characters are really unusual it just all seems so logical andanything that happens in the story after a while seems to make perfectsense.Every character in this book will stay with me for a long time.Murakami makes you feel like you know them personally and someparts of the story are quite sad and moving.So basically I just loved this book and recommend it to anyonewho wants to read something unusual and challenging.

Murakami me ha hecho percibir la vida de una manera mÃ¡s profunda y sensorial, encontrar belleza y magia incluso en la cotidianidad, la soledad, la rutina y la incertidumbre. Me siento retratado en sus personajes (sumergidos en el mar de sus miedos, dudas, recuerdos y anhelos) que en busca de respuestas y sentido a su vida encuentran consuelo en los libros, el arte, la mÃºsica, la naturaleza y perciben una luz cÃ¡lida de esperanza y amor en quienes sin interÃ©s alguno los ayudaron en su camino.

THIS is a book to reread that's for sure. I feel like I understood what happened but I think reading it a second time at a later date would cement that for me. The themes in this book are similar to Murakami's other work- isolation and change. I really loved the way our two main characters dealt with the changes in their lives. They both grew throughout the story. The writing in this was beautiful and although it isn't my favourite Murakami book I can see why so many people adore it. I need some time to think about this because it is kind of a lot to take in, especially that last 20%. Highly recommend though.

Phew! "You have the right to remain silent; anything you do or say will be held against you..." Should I remain silent, or should I go for it?That's my immediate reaction to this book. If ever I was confused about an ending, this is it. Am I correct in thinking that the reader is suppose to conclude the story, because the author had everything so mixed up that he was unable to do it himself? Or perhaps an ending in the real world would simply demolish the fantasy of this metaphysical journey through Greek mythology - especially Orpheus and the Oedipus complex, the classical music composers and literature? This tale becomes a metaphor for all of the above elements in the book.Well, three characters are definitely dead. That's a fact. The others are hanging around between childhood memories, reincarnation, and pure fantasy and I simply don't know where to bury them! Should it be in an alternative reality or reality? I simply do not know.Facts: Fifteen-year-old Kafka Tamura runs away from home-he wants to find his mother and sister-and decides to travel to Shikoku, since it is the opposite direction of where anyone would search to find him. He lands up in a private library, meets Oshima who, finally, understands the young man's thoughts, experiences and fantasies. Oshima understands the deeper dimensions of Kafka's troubled mind. After looking at a painting in the library, and listening to Miss Saeki's song 'Kafka on the shore' he finally realizes that it was his destiny that brought him there. Mysterious Miss Saeki was much more than he ever bargained for. The song was the riddle he needed to resolve.An old misunderstood man, Nakata, lives his life as a simpleton, talking to cats, and does not fight his destinies of illiteracy after a mysterious accident, as a nine-year-old boy, wiped out his memory completely. He is like a library without books. He does not understand desires, nor destiny. Yet, he meets Johnie Walker and the next moment there's blood everywhere, and nobody wants to believe his version of the story. He doesn't know why leeches, fish and sardines rain down from the open, cloudless skies when he opens his umbrella, but he does know the timeline of his future. He needs to leave Tokyo and head out to Shikoku, over the big bridge but doesn't know why. He only knows he should go.He hitch-hike there and at one of the truck stops he finally meets up with Hoshino, a truck driver, who never thanked his late grandfather for not giving up on him. So when these two characters meet, Hoshino decides to help this helpless old man reach his destiny to honor his grandfather's memory. Never in his wildest dreams would Hoshino have imagined that he would meat finger lickin' good Colonel Sanders who acted as a pimp, as well as reveal himself as God in a human conceptual disguise. A mystical bond between Kafka and Nakata plays itself out through the tale in a confusing, yet riveting drama, sprinkled with philosophical, as well satirical moments. Colonel Sanders had a weird sense of humor. It lightens up the drama considerably.To make the events work, the characters must be able to become "ghosts while they are still alive.â€The book starts out with a totally different possibility, when nine-year-old Nakata, as a member of the school group, walks into the woods with their teacher, in 1944, almost at the end of WWII, to collect mushrooms, and witness a strange flash in the sky, a silver flash, looking much like a reflection coming from an American B-29 bomber. While in the woods, all seventeen children fell unconscious and could not remember what happened. Sixteen recovered completely. Nakata, the seventeenth boy, did not regain consciousness and was moved to a military hospital where he eventually, after three weeks, woke up, his memory completely wiped out. He never regained the ability to read or write either.There is therefor never in indication in the beginning of the book that the story would venture off in a totally different direction and that the silver flash-event will never be fully developed or explained. There is no plausible solution to it. Perhaps it was used as a red herring?A murder is committed, the police are searching for the killer, which brings the suspense and drama alive and kept me reading. The characters were beautifully developed, each embedded in their absurd life stories. Dreams, fantasies and reality blend into an almost impossible, surreal, bizarre story with a strong sexual overtone. All the characters are likable. They are all lonely people who create their own realities to survive on their own. They all have different triggers for their cocooned, emotional-devoided lives. They are all searching for either the other half of their shadows, or the love they never find. Most of them want acceptance. They are all endearing, good people who were dealt a nasty hand and found the courage to take up the challenges. There is one common evil connection who held the strings of their lives in his hands. One of them had the ability to end it all, and he did.It is a good read. A masterful manipulation of the reader. A confusing, but exciting adventure. The reader is challenged with the existence of God. There is brutal violence and sexual innuendos and magical descriptions of the modern Japanese landscape. I felt deep empathy for all of the characters. Simply loved them all, except for the 'baddy'.If you don't mind finding the answers to all the unanswered questions left at the end, you will enjoy the book. But you've got to believe in ghosts, myths, and metaphysical magic. I will consider reading this author again. And I might consider rereading this book to come to a better understanding of the ending. However, I do not appreciate the clumsiness in leaving so many elements unresolved.I am not disappointed. Just highly confused. I enjoyed the experience though.

"Kafka on the Shore" by Haruki Murakami is a puzzling and captivating novel that enlaces multiple narratives, blurring the lines between reality and dreams, and exploring themes of identity, loneliness, and the search for meaning. The premise is brilliant: Kafka Tamura, a teenage boy who runs away from home to escape his father's curse, and Nakata, an elderly man who lost his memory in a childhood accident and possesses the ability to communicate with cats. Filled with mysterious occurrences, symbolic imagery, and philosophical musings, Murakami's prose is richly atmospheric, drawing readers into a surreal world where magical realism and mundane reality coexist seamlessly while inviting the reader to ponder the nature of existence and the interconnectedness of all things. Itâ€™s strength is that it does not provide easy answers or neatly tie up its narrative threads. Murakami revels in ambiguity, leaving many questions unanswered and encouraging interpretation of the story's events in a unique and immersive way.

1.5 StarsThe title was intriguing but the story was meh. Crow decides to run away from home when he turned 15. He takes his necessary stuff and a photograph of him and his sister as there were no other photos available. He had been very distant from his dad so mostly he was on his own reading books and training. Changed his name to Kafka and traveled to Takamatsu so that no one is able to find him. Stayed at a hotel and went to the Komura Library and gym to pass his time. One day he found himself outside a shrine covered in blood but didn't remember anything. The next day he went to the library and shared his problem with the librarian, who decided to help him and took him to his outhouse in the mountains until he arranged his job at the library as an Assistant. Kafka got the job and shifted in the library. His father was killed the night he had blood on his clothes but he didn't do it. The library was owned by Miss Saeki whom he started liking. She wrote a poem for her boyfriend who was killed; the song became a massive hit. She even told Kafka about her story of the lightning survivor interviews she took when she was in Tokyo. Kafka also remembered that once his father also survived lightning and it was then he started his profession as a sculptor seriously. The police tried to connects dots between Kafka and Nakata for the murder. Nakata was the one who confessed about the murder and was now headed towards Takamatsu. Nakata was the boy who lost his ability to read and write after the incident which took place during the second World War in the mountains where his teacher took him and others for an outdoor activity. The teacher later confessed that Nakata was a bright student but she slapped him before the incident and was very guilty of doing that. When he came back to his senses after many weeks he couldn't write or read hence his parents sent him away to his grandparents. There he learnt how to craft wood at a furniture shop and worked there for many years. After the furniture shop closed down he moved to the city where he got subsidy from the Governor and a special ride bus pass which covered his expenses. He had the ability to talk with cats so people came to him when their cats went missing, he found them and got paid. Once he was searching for a cat named Goma and got to know that a man kept stealing cats from the abandoned lot. He started staying at the lot for look out but didn't find Goma. A dog led him to Johnnie Walkers house who killed cats and in order to save Gome, Nakata stabbed him. Then went to the police to confess the murder but the police officer didn't take him seriously. Nakata was looking for a stone which he found and opened the entrance and met Miss Saeki at the library. She gave him a pile of stories of her life and told him to burn them, which he did. Miss Saeki was later found dead in her office. Nakata also died whereas Kafka decided to go back to Tokyo, complete his education and face the police. This book was great, though confusing and deeply philosophical at times. It is about a 15-year-old boy who runs from home and tries to create a life for himself in another city. All his life he's been tormented by his past, due to his mother and sister abandoning him and his life with a strange and distant father. He ends up working at a mysterious bookstore filled with collections of rare books, meeting the enigmatic bookkeeper, Oshima, and head of the library, Miss Saeki. The story is filled with strange occurrences of slipping out of the self to perform tasks such as murder, over realistic dreams of sex, unlocking the portal to a netherworld between life and death, and so on.This story challenges the preconception of time, reality, and dreams. It reconfirms our (mis)understanding that this world is full of mystical things beyond comprehension. It questions the meaning of freedom, forcing us to ponder our consciousness and our relationship to the larger universe.

Voleli ga ili ne, u svim Murakamijevim delima, prepoznaje se autentiÄnost kako u maniru pisanja tako i u atmosferi koju pisac nedri neobiÄnim likovima i zagonetkama na koje njegovi junaci traÅ¾e odgovore na svom putu samospoznaje. Za razliku od ranije proÄitanih Murakamijevih dela, koja mi se jesu svidela, Kafka na obali mora je prva njegova knjiga koje me je u potpunosti oduÅ¡evila i oÄarala. U glavi mi se vrzmala ideja kako bi ova knjiga bila izvrsna potka za Mijazakijev film. ÄŒudno i jedinstveno putovanje.5/5

Kafka On The Shore is definitely the weirdest book I have Ever Read In My Life!!! I have literally more than 100 questions about this book. So I searched for internet articles on Kafka On the Shore and Guess what I have found? In Haruki Murakami's own website--"Kafka on the Shore contains several riddles, but there arenâ€™t any solutions provided. Instead several of these riddles combine, and through their interaction the possibility of a solution takes shape. And the form this solution takes will be different for each reader. To put it another way, the riddles function as part of the solution. Itâ€™s hard to explain, but thatâ€™s the kind of novel I set out to write."Really Mr Murakami??ğŸ˜’ *Goes to build my own theories*Murakami recieved more than 8000 questions in 3 months about this book and he answered 1200 of them personally. Now you can think of how many riddles this book contains. Book covers the story of Two Characters Kafka Tamura(15yo boy) and Mr Nakata(60yo man) in alternate chapters. But their stories somehow intertwined with each other.The characters on this book are best part. They are really diverse to each in every aspects of the life. You will learn a lot from them.Book is full of weird elements from Sprit World to Talking Cats, Flute made up of cats soul to Falling fish from the sky!I literally can not define the weirdness of this book in words. While reading this book, every once in a while I was like what the heck did just happened?? This book contains various western culture refrences. You will get a lot of musical refrences from The Beatles to Beethoven's Archduke Trio. It is 615 pages long but you will not drift off while reading. This book confuses reader and make them think way too much but don't let them abandon the book that's the real beauty of book. Kafka on the Shore makes sense but also doesn't!One thing I can say about Murakami, his way of describing things is just Wondrous. It literally feels as though you are living in that world with those very characters. He's truly a genius. 
"Everyone of us is losing something precious to us. Lost opportunities, lost possibilities, feelings we can never get back. Thatâ€™s part what it means to be alive. But inside our heads, thereâ€™s a room where we store those memories. And to understand the workings of our own heart we have to keep on making new reference cards. We have to dust things off every once in a while, let in fresh air, change the water in flower bases. In other words, youâ€™ll live life in your own private library."

To read Kafka on the Shore is to weave through the malleable boundary between reality and fantasy, to meet philosophical prostitute, talking cats, and characters like Johnny Walker and Colonel Sanders, to dream of the dialectics of Hegal and the continuous time of Bergson converging with the Oedipal complex, to journey into Haruki Murakamiâ€™s imagination. I want to know whether Kafka killed his father, whether the librarian was his mother, and whether he was dreaming when he met his mother. I want to know whether Nakata was just fantasizing that he could talk to cats. But as in Murakamiâ€™s other two novels, The Wind Up Bird Chronicle and Hardboiled Wonderland and the End of the World, reality and dream synthesize into a world that transcends truth or illusion. And Murakami takes us along his wonderland and shows what we too could imagine if we free our minds from the biases, the limits, and the cannots we have accepted as truth. Reality almost seems sterile when we immerse ourselves in Murakamiâ€™s surrealism. And I invite you to dream along with Murakami on a shore far into the sea of imagination where a songâ€™s lyrics echo back into reality.  Haruki Murakami

Î•Î¯Î½Î±Î¹ Ï„Î± Î²Î»Î­Ï†Î±ÏÎ¬ Î¼Î¿Ï…Î´Î¹Î¬Ï†Î±Î½ÎµÏ‚ Î±Ï…Î»Î±Î¯ÎµÏ‚.ÎŒÏ„Î±Î½ Ï„Î± Î±Î½Î¿Î¯Î³Ï‰ Î²Î»Î­Ï€Ï‰Î¼Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Ï… ÏŒ,Ï„Î¹ ÎºÎ¹ Î±Î½ Ï„ÏÏ‡ÎµÎ¹.ÎŒÏ„Î±Î½ Ï„Î± ÎºÎ»ÎµÎ¯Î½Ï‰ Î²Î»Î­Ï€Ï‰Î¼Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Ï… ÏŒ,Ï„Î¹ Ï€Î¿Î¸Ï.Lynchian MetamorphosisThe vague feeling of an upcoming tragedyThe transparent world of dreams and fantasy and their consequencesKafka and Oedipus meet only to make things greater and complicated. The unity of action, place and time itâ€™s something essential in Greek Tragedy according to Aristotles, but Murakami present his story with an elusive and hallucinatory way. A puzzle, a labyrinth, a profoundly moving yet complex tale of fate, adulthood and responsibility. Sometimes the allegories, the situations and even the feelings canâ€™t always be explained or occasionally seem a bit forced . Also the dialogues seem weird and forced but that bizarreness is what I enjoy most. Nakata and Oshima are so great characters that I canâ€™t even put it in words. The trip was intriguing and completely fantastic. Murakami make his worlds with his own rules but so close to reality, that seem only a version among thousand others. And his version always get under your skin somehow as if it was completely tangible. His storytelling is what I love the most about this author but there are a few things here or there that put me off. Something is missing as the pieces of the puzzle are not in their place, at least not all of them. But it doesnâ€™t have to everything make sense, doesnâ€™t it ?

Mai avrei pensato di leggere un libro cosÃ¬ onirico, surreale . Un libro dove i gatti parlano , dove pesci e sanguisughe cadono dal cielo come pioggia , maledizioni, profezie , sogni e realtÃ  che si fondono in unâ€™unica dimensione . Con Murakami mi sono lasciata trasportare e mi sono fidata della sua bellissima scrittura e ho deciso di seguirlo , di non farmi troppe domande e lasciarmi coinvolgere da queste sue atmosfere cosÃ¬ intime e delicate , forti e misteriose . Murakami Ã¨ stato molto abile a creare fin dalle prime pagine una forte tensione , una sorta di suspense che mi ha spinto a continuare ad andare avanti , quasi fosse un giallo da risolvere . Il protagonista ,Tamura, compie un viaggio con direzione per la formazione del proprio io , infatti nonostante le sue arie da adulto resta comunque un quindicenne alla ricerca di se e del proprio posto nel mondo . Nakata il coprotagonista con la sua storia parallela seguirÃ  il destino del protagonista , ed Ã¨ lâ€™esatto opposto, un uomo totalmente privo di interioritÃ  , avvolto da una luce e da una storia misteriosa , capace di cose al tempo stesso ingenue e sovrumane . Il romanzo ha una struttura talmente ben congeniale nei tempi narrativi da rendere il lettore impossibilitato a staccarsi dalle pagine . Un libro affascinante e magnetico .
