What a lovely book! I think I enjoyed it even more than I did 1Q84. I have to admit I did not totally understand it but I am sure I was not supposed to and I did not try really hard. I just let the beautiful prose wash over me and enjoyed all the delightful characters. How can you not love someone who can talk to cats? This was actually a gripping story or rather two gripping stories which eventually merged into one. Very clever, very well written and a total pleasure to read.

Dopo Dance Dance Dance ho da poco terminato questo altro capolavoro di Murakami, Kafka sulla spiaggia. Stupendo, onirico, filosofico... vorrei poter citare mille passaggi del romanzo, ma lo spazio non me lo permette. Posso solo dire una cosa: leggere Murakami Ã¨ sempre trasformante. E non aggiungo altro.

I have missed many metro stops reading this. My mother has yelled at me many times for not completing my applications before finishing this. I'm probably flunking my Deutsch exam because I binge-read this. Full RTC.

My first fiction by Murakami and I think I'm hooked. This was a beautiful (and deeply weird) book. But it's not weird for weird's sake. The whole thing seems allegorical of mythological--so the "magical" elements really fused into the story. I can't wait to read more.
Actual rating: 4.75This book was... eccentric.Some chapters gave me goosebumps and I still dont know why.Overall, I found this still a nice read.

Kafka on the Shore is in many ways a typical Murakami novel. It contains parallel narratives, long philosophical passages (mostly in a form of monologues and dialogues), warped time, numerous music and literature references, talking cats and dream sequences. Not to say that if you have read one Murakami novel, you have read them all, for I find them all worthy in their own way. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that this writer does employ an unique and recognizable writing style that might feel repetitive to some. Once you have read quite a bit of Murakami, it will be easy for you to notice distinct patterns in his writing. Not that I'm complaining. I've been a fan of his writing for years. I find his prose mesmerizing and powerful and only occasionally a bit repetitive and overwhelming. I would say that my feelings for Murakami's writing are similar to what I feel towards cats and coffee- an intense liking. You could say that his novels are something I can never get enough of. I don't care if his plot are sometimes clumsy, convenient or/and illogical (not referring to surreal elements obviously, I don't expect logic from that, just from the regular parts), because you know his books would be worth reading for those wonderfully philosophical passages alone. If there weren't for the philosophy and wisdom that can be found in them, his books would be worth reading just for the lyrical prose or the brilliant culture references. What I'm trying to say is that one can really learn a thing or two by reading his books. I get that Murakami is not everyone's cup of tea, though. If you like high paced novels filled with active protagonists, without digressions but with logical plots twists and written in a simple narrative style, well then Murakami is NOT for you. I'm a reader that loves ambiguity but I must admit that Murakami's ambiguity is at times a bit too much even for me. I don't see how someone who hates ambiguity and magic realism could like him at all.  I borrowed Kafka on the Shore from the library yesterday and read it in one setting. I found it absolutely mesmerizing and have basically eaten both lunch and dinner with a book in hand. What makes this novel different from the other Murakami's books I read? Hm, there seems to be more of a Oedipus motif in this one. Incest is a big part of this novel and even if it is not certain has it really happened or not (much of it remains a mystery), it is definitely present. If that particular subject is something you can't bear yourself to read about, this is not a book for you. Sexuality is definitely a part of Murakami's writing, but in this one there is more of a focus on the Oedipus complex (albeit it is not the central theme). In addition, this novel has a number of references to Greek tragedies. Now, references to Western literature are always present in Murakami's writing, but I don't recall the Greek tragedies being as important to other novels as they were for this one. Coming back to the Oedipus myth, I found this passage from an interview with Murakami very interesting because he seems to say that the Oedipus myth was not something he had in mind when he set to writing:What made you want to retell the Oedipus myth? Did you have a plan to do this when you started Kafka On The Shore or did it come about during the writing?The Oedipus myth is just one of several motifs and isnâ€™t necessarily the central element in the novel. From the start I planned to write about about a fifteen-year-old boy who runs away from his sinister father and sets off on a journey in search of his mother. This naturally linked up with the Oedipus myth. But as I recall, I didnâ€™t have that myth in mind at the beginning. Myths are the prototype for all stories. When we write a story on our own it canâ€™t help but link up with all sorts of myths. Myths are like a reservoir containing every story there is.I do believe that Murakami didn't plan to write another Oedipus myth, but it is hard to escape the similarities both plot wise and style wise. Whether we like it or not, our sexual development from a psychological perspective is always under the influence of parental figures. The Oedipus complex is just a normal phase of a child's development, or so the psychologist say. It is not a disease or a disorder, it's just a phase. However, when a child lacks a parental figure or has issues with it (as our protagonist does), then things get more complicated. What I want to say is that while Murakami's writing does expand to this myth, it is also because myths are a big part of who we are as humans and as such reflect our psychological and emotional being. The whole Oedipus motif isn't perhaps central to this novel but it is an important part of it as are the themes of growing up, sexuality, isolation and so on. Isolation and individuality are perhaps more important as motifs then the Oedipus complex, but perhaps we could say that they all tie together. How to keep one's individuality but still develop meaningful relationships? How to let go of past tragedies and keep one's sanity in this crazy violent world? How to escape isolation in the modern world? Those are the questions that I feel this novel asks and perhaps even tries to answer. The protagonist of this novel is named after Kafka (or rather named himself after Kafka). Murakami admits to his love for this author. However, Murakami never tries to copy Kafka and that's something worth acknowledging. There are references to Kafka's works but also to other works of literature so if you're expecting this book to be all about Kafka, it is not. There is so much more I could say about this novel, but my goodreads review has to end sooner or later and this seems as a good place to end it as any (I will probably publish a longer version on my blog).  What follows is another passage from Murakami's interview that caught my eye:...Before â€œpostmodernismâ€ became a buzzword, Franz Kafka explored that particular condition of isolation associated with a post-nuclear, new-millennium world. Did you name your protagonist after him to draw out these themes, or were there other reasons?It goes without saying that Kafka is one of my very favorite writers. But I donâ€™t think my novels or characters are directly influenced by him. What I mean is, Kafkaâ€™s fictional world is already so complete that trying to follow in his steps is not just pointless, but quite risky, too. What I see myself doing, rather, is writing novels where, in my own way, I dismantle the fictional world of Kafka that itself dismantled the existing novelistic system. One could view this as a kind of homage to Kafka, I suppose. To tell the truth, I donâ€™t really have a firm grasp of whatâ€™s meant by postmodernism, but I do have the sense that what Iâ€™m trying to do is slightly different. At any rate, what Iâ€™d like to be is a unique writer whoâ€™s different from everybody else. I want to be a writer who tells stories unlike other writersâ€™.*SOURCE FOR THE INTERVIEW WITH MURAKAMI THAT I QUOTED: http://www.harukimurakami.com/q_and_a...

First, let me try and put it in simple terms. This book from the beginning to the end just had me going "What the actual F***??" In complicated terms (still simple, I'm just going with the rhythm here). this book left my brain muddled, making me rethink the whole existence of my life, looking back to see what is reality and what is not. All in all it just left me as a pile of confused goo. goo because I cannot think of anything else to describe myself. I am as attractive as a pile of goo but now I am a confused one to add to it. Imagine me as the emjoi with a question mark above it. Enough of this, now to the review.Although I have reading for the majority of my life, this year was the year I finally picked up Haruki Murakami. Mostly due to the fact that I had a weird sense where I wanted to start with Norwegian Wood and I could not find a decent copy anywhere until recently. Finally I did and as most of the Murakami fans, I was left with a certain befuddled sense of satisfaction at the end of the book. That is the best way I can explain all of the times that I finished a Murakami book. It is without doubt that during any translation much of the essence of the book is lost in it. Thus I am always skeptical of translations. Many translators try their best to give it to us as it is but sometimes it is just lost. Still Murakami's books manages to shine through. the certain warped yet straight forward aspect of Murakami's writings always manages to shine through in the translations. Murakami's books are never the normal sort of book you would pick. It is the type of book that you should pick up when you know you have enough time to thoroughly enjoy it, without any interuptions because in my opinion, Murakami has that innate ability to pick his readers up and transport them to the other world where no one is quite sure how they got there. In a certain aspect I do not think even our characters know how they got there, better yet I don't think Murakami knowa either. This in a way seemed to be the running theme in Kafka on The Shore. Every chapter just made the story more tangled than really giving a certain sense of conclusion. I am still trying to wrap my brain around the fact of what is the actual plot of the story, what was the meaning of all the events and like I said in the beginning, more than anything I feel as if I am trapped in a limbo where I cannot figure if I am living a dream or if this is all reality. This my friend, was the moment that I knew Murakami is true genius in a weird convulated way, but a genius nonetheless. At least in my eyes. Truth be told by the end of the novel, I was left with a headache, partly by too much reading and partly by the fact I forgot to blow dry my hair and I felt my nose clog reaching towards a headache at the end. Whatever the reasons were, this book left me with an addled brain. I felt as if everthing I knew was taken out of my brain and rearranged within. Which I still don't know if it was good or not. This by any chance does not mean I disliked the book. As a matter of fact it is quite the opposite or something in the middle. I loved it in the most weird manner but it was almost as if I was in a toxic yet addictive relationship. It gave me satisfaction but in the back of my mind I always wanted to leave it and at the end when I did, it felt rather good. The memories built during that time was worth the memories of a life time. So yes Mr. Murakami, you are forever going to be that toxic lover for me that I will keep going back to despite knowing that you will leave me with scars.

To date I've read 13 books by Haruki Murakami in translation. I find his works to be a mix of the passable, the very good, and the mediocre. Kafka on the Shore belongs squarely to the last category. I was unimpressed by this long novel about incest, animal cruelty, music, destiny, and growing up. The translation by Philip Gabriel reads well but Murakami comes across as an minor writer, a mere crowd-pleaser. The repetitions of sentences and phrases are irritating. Granted that repetitions are used to imitate a piece of music, the flat Hemingway-esque prose can't save it from sounding contrived and didactic. The title refers both to a musical composition and a painting. But references to these art forms cannot help this piece of fiction approach the level of a good read. The plot just plods along, the disparate themes woven into a pointless puzzle. The puzzle is laid on a Scrabble board, the pieces being letter tiles sharply cut at the edges. There's no challenge to deciphering it, no net benefit to be had. His novel Norwegian Wood is, I think, more worthwhile pointlessness than this. The novel is, moreover, a poor example of a "magical realist" novel as magic here is utilized without "logic." My benchmarks for a good magical novel are One Hundred Years of Solitude, where fantastical elements are tightly integrated into the story, and The Literary Conference by CÃ©sar Aira, where magic is uncontrollable, wreaking havoc as it escapes from the grasp of the writer. The magic of Murakami is neither mysterious nor crude. It is just plain dry old magic. A multitude of fishes falls from the sky, period. Leeches fall from the sky, period. The surreal worlding of magic and mystery is here not to be accepted as inevitable but unbelievable. Very unlike the stifling nightmare world of its namesake writer Kafka, or the logical labyrinths of a Borges, or even the sustained suspension of disbelief in Murakamiâ€™s own A Wild Sheep Chase. The magic of Kafka on the Shore is without flair or drama. In its pure form, wry and deadpan, magic redounds to an unintended humor. Finally, the novel suffers from overkill: too much explanation trying to â€œjustifyâ€ the incest, too much self-help crap undermining the charactersâ€™ consciousness. This self-help streak is prefigured in Dance Dance Dance but reached a young adult fever-pitch here. Save for some interesting scenes with the old man Nakata, the book is otherwise overrated.

Yesterday, today, tomorrow - they'd all blur into one. Like an anchorless ship, time floats aimlessly across the broad sea.3.5* to the author Murakami on what was my first Japanese novel. Reflecting back on the book has provided me with mixed feelings. The story was strange and confusing and parts didn't make sense, however the book is a beautiful and melodious read.Kafka On The Shore has a very philosophical feel to it due to the protagonist's character. Kafka is an adolescent with the world on his shoulders, every thought pondered, every action has the consequence considered. In terms of thought pattern alone, I felt really connected to Kafka.The story itself is appealing from the start, there's a sense of mystery for each story within. The issue was tying all of it together and satisfying the reader with the outcome. Although it was an enjoyable read, this was purely down to the authors writing skills and not the story itself.Murakami toys with the past, the present, the reality and even the astral plane, it's all considered and connected. The irony stems from the fact that every character within the book appears to be independent and disconnected from everyone around them.To summarise, the book highlights challenges we all come across in life as we develop as individuals and does so in a relatable way. That being said, the story has some very strange parts which I couldn't really get my head around.If any of you fellow Goodreads friends have read any Murakami/Japanese novels, what was it like?Thanks for reading

Murakami's novels are always a little hard to get through, because they are rather long, and more often than not, very little actually happens throughout them. They are full of a myriad of tedious details, illogical plot twists, and unbelievable happenings. However despite all of this, I find them to be amazing novels that affect me on a level very different than the average book. Kafka on the Shore was no exception, and listening to it in audiobook form only helped to enhance the experience.I feel that Murakami takes a combination of both a Shinto and Zen experience, and spins it into a tangible form. The large amount of detail used to describe the scenes, settings, and actions of the characters creates an amazing sense of reality. It's almost as if the plot and the things that the characters learn are inconsequential, while the experience and sense of the present is of utmost importance. I'm not sure exactly how to relate the hypnotic spell that Murakami weaves, but the temperature, quality, smell, sense, and taste of the world we live in is reflected in his writing. It's as if the book presents all of these mundane details so that they can be noted, experienced, and appreciated.I'm not sure if anyone else gets the same thing out of his writing. It is a bit weird, quirky, and sometimes even disturbing. Not everything is meant to be taken logically in the book. Plot, characters, and themes don't always play out in a logical fashion, but I think the everything is meant to be taken in a more spiritual, less causual sense.

My third Murakami and it becomes clear that he always falls back on almost the same ingredients: main characters that are like unwritten sheets, they become involved in mysterious, often surreal events and go on a quest, in a environment with magic realistic elements; also many references to western high culture and to Japanese culture, a few sadistic scenes and regularly explicit sex, and finally also a very floating, natural style (like running water, I wrote earlier). It remains a compelling mix but in this novel the chemistry doesnâ€™t really work. First of all, the pace is very slow: only after the middle of the book (after 300 pages!) the story picks up pace; Murakami occasionally fits in beautiful philosophical considerations, but in the end he does little with them; also the whole intrigue bogs down a bit especially because of some strange passages that seem to have no function whatsoever (the cruel cat killer for instance). In short, it still is fun to wonder around in Murakami land, but this book does not reach the level of the previous ones. (2.5 stars)

Ho voluto dargli una chance, perchÃ© non capivo il motivo per cui un autore tanto apprezzato da molti a me desse quasi fastidio. Anche in questo percorso di formazione ci sono dei personaggi assurdi e i protagonisti compiono azioni altrettanto illogiche, ma questa volta si giustifica tutto in un ambito onirico (la parola piÃ¹ usata da tutti per questo libro, ma azzeccata).Il linguaggio Ã¨ lieve e delicato e la storia incuriosisce.Un ottima lettura.

Metaphor. The whole book is a metaphor. For what? You decide. Love, loss, music, beauty. Life. It reads like a journey to self, and away from self, and back to self again, seen through the eyes of a 15-year-old boy. Itâ€™s almost like a melody, like Beethovenâ€™s Moonlight in C Minor, only written with words. There are no explanations to the strange and forbidden and at times bloody things that happen to Kafka, the boy who leaves home to find home and finds himself instead, him, his body and his mind, the only home heâ€™ll ever get. There is the life of an elderly man who is not very smart, the man who can talk to cats, the man whose path crosses with that of Kafka. There are murders, horrific scenes of things torn apart, things you know, things that will scare you, and things you canâ€™t imagine. And woods, dark scary woods. And ghosts. And cats, of course. And plenty of cooking dinners and eating udon noodles and discussing beautiful music and books and libraries and chirping birds and murders, bizarre murders that leave you in the dark until you see that itâ€™s all a metaphor, a play on Oedipus complex. The boy. His mother. His jealousy. His father. His sister. I was wondering what kept me glued to this book. Nothing much happens there, really, not in the sense of urgent things like crazy chases or horrifying antagonists pursuing characters with sharp shiny knives. The pace is slow, rather leisurely, and yet it grips you and holds you in the throes of what life is about. Confusion. Feelings. Thoughts. Search for love. For good. For meaning. Any kind of meaning. And then the understanding that there is no meaning to any of it. Only what we make of it, out of fear. I must say, the book is a delight because itâ€™s the only one Iâ€™ve read that is narrated in first, second, and third person. A treat for any writer to read and study. Youâ€™ll find fantasy here, and magical realism, too. A touch of horror. Suspense. Sly quiet humor. And lots of sexuality, tender and violent and taboo. Beautiful. Read it. It reads like music.

"Can nothingness increase?"Devastatingly beautiful, profound and affecting exploration on identity and compassion.Murakami writes of a hauntingly surreal inner reality of the human condition, evoking a sense of otherworldly beauty and anguish within a soul; infused with compelling philosophical questions, existential contemplation and search for self.This kept me completely transfixed; at times moved to tears, both by the sheer overwhelming pathos or by how closely the presented experiences touched.The unassumingly progressing story is carried by a cast of charming and amiable personalities, from interactions of astuteness and hilarity, to arresting moments of dejection and ferocity.This was my first (fully engaged) Murakami, and I am left profusely better for it. Grateful to have this to add to my list of all time favorites, and can't wait to get to experience more of Murakami's entirely entrancing perception.(Barrett's and Le Sueur's narrations were excellently expressive. And there's more immediate thoughts in the reading updates below.)._____Edit 31/08/2022: having read several more works from Murakami's oeuvre since, this still remains a lone shining star above all the rest of them. "Peak Murakami".

I went on a Murakami reading binge in 2009, and suddenly found myself hitting a wall. What I had started out loving started to overwhelm and suffocate me. I knew I needed a break from him for a while.I did take a break from the break to read 1Q84, which I really enjoyed. As I listened to the audiobook of this novel, I found myself wishing I'd read this prior to 1Q84. Some of the themes are the same, and I don't just mean the silly themes like cats and pasta and music, but shifting realities and not being sure about who you are on many levels. They seem more concise in this novel, and I think having this experience first would have made 1Q84 even better.I enjoyed the audio. The two narrators bring completely different feelings to the different sections, and the novel shifts back and forth between the narratives of Kafka and Nakata. I enjoyed the haven of the library and the very helpful librarian, but that might have been the only moment of reality in this book. ;)Murakami always sends me off to listen to music, not just by work but certain performances of a work. I spent the afternoon listening to the Archduke Trio (Beethoven) as performed by the "Million Dollar Trio." Great stuff.

On my second read, I loved it less. There is great inventiveness and whimsy of course. The story also derives much power from the way it mixes a mythic form of story telling with matter-of-fact depictions of modern life. But without the constant surprise that the book gave me on my first read, when so many things were unexpected, I began to notice that the story is empty of any human happenings that matter. I felt a little pushed-around as I read, rather than feeling that the story happened organically. I prefer After the Quake where the mystical happenings seemed to draw me into a new perspective on the 1995 Kobe earthquake rather than what I felt here--not connected with anything real about the world.

This book like many of the novels of Haruki Murakami is about a young man discovering about himself. This time it is through the eyes of a fifteen year old who has run away from his dad in the city of Tokyo to the small town of Takamatsu, where he spends his time at a local small private library where he meets Oshima who looks after him, and the owner of the library, Miss Saeki. This is the story of how he finds about the past, and discovers something magical.

Murakami: The Philospher of Fiction
This is my third Murakami book. This first was Norwegian Wood, followed by The Wind Up Bird Chronicle. I actually thought my Murakami days were done after the later mentioned, I really had finished with Murakamis style of writing and weird ambling metaphysical plots. However, after forgetting to bring a book whilst staying at a friend's house for a three day job in central London, I found this classic in my hands.I say 'classic' as this has already been dubbed one way before I ever even knew the author exsisted. Unfortunately this is my least favourite of the three I've read. This may be down to the fact I never actually picked this up with the intention to finish (a foolish thought, as any goodreads follower would know) and as such everything beyond the first twenty pages or so was a struggle. Keeping this short- seeing as there's only a couple of hundred reviews or so on this book already- I had only one major gripe with the book. I acknowledge Murakamis plots aren't meant to make sense in the traditional way. His novels read more as philosophical outings into various topics, mostly seen through the eyes of some paradoxically normal-yet-oh-so-weird character. That's what I loved about his previous novels and what made them very refreshing when first reading them. However, I always grasped the core message throughout these reads. This wasn't the case for Kafka on the Shore. It's obviously an adolescents journey to adulthood (with one Hell of an Oedipus complex inbetween), but also a discussion on politics, gender identity, mythology, conspiracy theories and mental health as well. None of these topics gel particularly well though, and at times it feels as though Murakami is trying to fit a character story within a statement, within a coded message, about contemporary society. The result being quite a rambling plot. Coupled with a few awkward sex scenes and some slightly off character interactions, this makes for a jarring read. Perhaps I wouldn't be saying this if were my first round with the author but it certainly didn't captivate my attention as the previous novels did. In other words, the fictional aspect of this story and cogs that fit together to make a fluid plot didn't really come together.So why the four stars? Because despite this problem, Murakami is a genius writer. This is an author who has even admitted he doesn't really hold meetings with himself and make up plots (Think JK Rowling, on a train, creating the world of Harry Potter) so much as he sits down and just starts writing whatever comes to his head. He is the ultimate off-hand author with a knack for connecting with people from different backgrounds all over the world, in subjects we can all understand, and as such his work utter reflects this nature. His stories ask for patience from his readers and a reflective, almost meditative outlook on life. Not to mention his complete rejection of any traditional beginning, middle and end, three-point structure (at least to some degree). He is the antithesis to what western writers and readers expect from an author. Instead of taking his readers on a classical Odysseus style journey, he makes contemplative stories that without the plot or fictional aspect, really could be notes from meditations by Marcus Aurelius. As such, I just feel Murakami missed the mark slightly with this one. That's it. Nothing more, nothing less. Considering this is a veteran author with many, many books under his belt, it's quite a surprise he doesn't have more misses than hits with the above described style of writing.But then it wouldn't be Haruki Murakami if that were the case.Put with your books under philosophy, not fiction.

6/5/2010 review:If you want to get swept away and really dive into a story, stop whatever you are doing and find a way to get your hands on a copy of this book. This is an excellent book. I am not a fast reader. I read relatively slowly and I always read each and every word, taking it all in (kind of like Kafka himself). I don't think that there is any other way to read this book. Every word is important. Every sentence means something. If you are someone who likes to get to it, this book might not be the one for you. You have to be someone who kind of doesn't mind hanging on and on and just going along for the ride. I could see how someone could get frustrated with this book. But not me. I loved every page. I loved EVERY character! I'm not sure that has ever happened before... I really, really love Kafka and Oshima and I LOVED Colonel Sanders and Hoshino. Okay, I loved every character. There were so many great lines in this book, I wish I marked them all down, but that can get distracting. But I did manage to underline these that I really loved:"Being really clean is sometimes the most important thing there is" (Kafka)"Oshima told me people can't be in two places at once, but I think it's possible. In fact, I'm sure of it. While people are alive, people can become ghosts." (Kafka)"I'm appearing here in human form, but I'm neither god nor Buddah. My heart works differently from humans' hearts because I don't have any feelings. That's what it means" (Colonel Sanders)"Listen up - there's no war that will end all wars" (Crow)I really got this book. I loved this book. I'm so glad that some very nice person was willing to translate this great book for English readers. Thank you!!!6/15/2014 review:Every time I read this book I go deeper into the story. This just may be my favorite book in the world. THIS time I really enjoyed and appreciated the characters of Hoshino, our unsung hero, and Colonel Sanders, our abstract concept. As always, I love Oshima. When I look at the cover of my edition, I see Oshima: serious, intelligent, introspective, compassionate, and mysterious, at least at first. The mystery of Oshima fades as the story is told, and by the end of the book, Oshima is our dearest friend. I think I first fell in love with this book because of what Kafka does: he runs away and goes to live in a little room in a small, private library. The library is peaceful, wonderful, quiet, unique, special. Oshima works there, and I want to know Oshima. I want him to talk to me everyday in the same way he talks to Kafka. I could listen to Oshima go on for hours. I never get tired of this book. I already feel like starting again from page one. I love it.6/22/2017: I never get tired of reading this book. I loved Hoshino so much this time.

42nd book of 2020.This Murakami is one of the ones I've been wanting to read since getting into him (previously it was this and The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle, review here), but I kept my promise of reading him in order of publication starting from the very beginning - I've fought my way here. Actually, fought makes it sound like it's been hard, it hasn't. It's been joyous. Kafka on the Shore has many words surrounding it, Messy, Inconclusive, Confusing, Weird, Boring...only some of which are true. Firstly, boring? I didn't think so, at all. Messy? Possibly, in a wonderfully scattered Slaughterhouse-Five kind of way: controlled messiness. Confusing? Well, that's Murakami, simple but also confusing, but that's why we keep reading. Weird? Of course. Inconclusive? That's an interesting one - because, yes.Things are tied up, but also not at all. There's a nice ending, in fact, one of my favourite new last lines from Murakami, but there's much still unclear. Even the central question of the novel is left as 'You already know the answer' to our protagonist, Kafka Tamura. We can guess, as readers, but we don't know - only Kafka does. In fact, there are several main characters and I wonder what was their purpose, or else where did they fit in the story? They did, somehow, but it is not overtly clear. Things are not overtly clear in this novel. Is it frustrating? No, oddly. At its heart is a runaway 15 year old and an Oedipus curse. I won't spoil anything. We've a sentient (possibly non-existent) crow, a lorry driver, an old man who can talk to cats, flutes made from the souls of cats, fish raining from the sky, leeches raining from the sky, a (magical?) stone, a philosophy student whore, Colonel Sanders the KFC guy (or is it?), WWII soldiers, un-aged, a cabin in a forest like some Kerouac scene, lots of music and books and Beethoven. A little bit of Radiohead. Sex, sure. A library. A cross-gender librarian. A UFO... There are two story-line strands that are seemingly unconnected and the whole novel is hinged on the feeling that somewhere and somehow these strands are inevitably coming closer and closer together and will meet at some climax. It's enough to keep us going, a spell. I can't say why I loved this book as I often can't with Murakami. I rate this below The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle, and maybe that is still even below Dance Dance Dance (review here). Not many people share my stance but I think the latter is still my favourite Murakami. So far. I don't have many left. I'm rushing towards the end, inevitably. But what happens when I get there?

Normally, I'm skeptical of the word metaphysical and how that word is often misused. In the case of Haruki Murakami's brilliant Kafka on the Shore, the word metaphysical correctly suits the overall mood and fancy of this novel. Murakami paints a surreal yet easily identifiable Japan in which a 15-year-old boy named Kafka is dead set on running away as fast as he can from a gruesome and hideous prophecy - he ends up on a seaside town far from his Tokyo home - all the while looking for the mother and sister he never knew. Meanwhile, an illiterate simpleton named Nakata, who has the uncanny ability to speak with cats, is suddenly drawn against his will towards Kafka. Much like the works of Franz Kafka - and the use of the name "Kafka" in this novel is by no means coincidental - Murakami places his characters in situations that are far beyond their control, for reasons they can't fathom or understand. The metaphysical odyssey both Kafka and Nakata undertake is rife with strange occurrences: fish falling from the sky, a quest for a specific entrance rock, an apparition posing as a pimp disguised as Colonel Sanders, 2 soldiers who went AWOL during WWII and yet are still alive and hiding in a forest, just to name a few. Yet none of these occurrences will have you questioning the implausibility of it all; Murakami weaves a magical, tender, bittersweet, often gruesome, ultimately very funny tale of the hidden things outside of our understanding that sometimes take control of us. This was my first venture into the works of Haruki Murakami, and it won't be the last. I now have a new favorite author, and I consider myself very privileged to have read the great master. Kafka on the Shore is easily one of the best novels I've read, and it's quickly assumed a high position as one of my favorites.

Kafka on the Shore: One of Murakamiâ€™s BestHoshino: You know, I'm not really big on reading and fancy words. I'm just getting by every day, and if I can work, eat, drink, maybe get laid, then I'm pretty happy. I don't know what the big deal is about this Murakami guy. People act like he's some kind of genius, but when I ask what his books are about, they can't explain it! Do you get it, Nakata?Nakata: I'm sorry, Mr. Hoshino, Nakata is not a very smart person and he doesn't understand difficult books. So I can't answer your question. But I do know lots of cats who are smarter and might be able to help you. Should I ask them?Hoshino: Cats? Ask them about Murakami? What's the point of that? Cats just like to do their own thing and skulk around at night. They couldn't care less about books or famous authors. Neither do I.I respect they way you live, Nakata. You're an interesting guy, different but I like that. And what's the point of discussing a book? Either you liked it or you didn't. That's all that matters.Nakata: I don't know about all that, but I do know Nakata loves to have a bowl of eel sometimes, that makes me very happy. Would you like to go have some eel together?Hoshino: I thought you'd never ask. Let's go.

Ah, Murakami-san. I've quite liked some of your work, but the more surreal of your novels have always seemed to fall flat for me.Kafka on the Shore is perhaps the most surreal novel of his I've read, and it's trash. I'm sure that statement will ruffle some feathers, and I'm sure some will simply retort that I 'didn't get it', but in my opinion Kafka on the Shore is utter nonsense with very little substance and almost nothing beyond some unique imagery to make it a worthwhile endeavor to carve through its near-500 pages of bullshit.Reading Kafka on the Shore is like meeting an oddball at a party. A skinny fellow at the snack stand with dyed blue hair and wearing a smart blue blazer and tie, sipping a non-alcoholic selzer-water and eating fritos dipped in honey mustard. What a curious fellow, you think, he must be interesting! You chat him up about all manner of things; turns out he's actually a lepidopterist. Whoa, never met one of those before! He doesn't drink, nor use recreational drugs, because he believes they're poison and wants to keep his body and mind sharp. He has incredibly deep knowledge about things you've never even considered. His job is to manage inventories of cold film storage for classic TV shows, so he spends his days around golden age television cans and regales you with odd stories about Car 54 and Gunsmoke and how TV just ain't how it used to be. You take down his number and want to hang out with him to hear more about these things you've never thought about; to learn more about the dark corners of life experience you've never even considered.You hang out with this individual a few more times, learning more and more. But eventually, something starts to bother you. Beyond these oddball pursuits, you begin to get a sense that there's just not much there. You eventually learn he simply hates the taste of beer, and he actually does smoke marijuana every so often. He doesn't actually collect butterflies yet, though he is interested in the hobby. At the moment he just likes to read a lot of Nabokov and finds the hobby a fascinating affectation, so he seeks to emulate it. His vocation is not something he's actually passionate or romantic aboutâ€”he simply works part time on contract at a warehouse that happens to store these classic TV film canisters, and he's caught a glimpse of them before.You realize he's just a guy. A regular dude. There's really not all that much special about him. He goes to work, he comes home, he pays his bills. The things he recognizes as being cool are pretty interesting, you admit, but he doesn't have such a deep, compelling knowledge of them after all.He has nothing to say beyond, "Hey man, check this out. Isn't this pretty cool?".That's Murakami's fiction to me.On the surface Murakami's work seems profound, different, fresh, compelling. But when you dig a bit deeper, there's very little actual substance there. Murakami's fiction is very light on story and humanity, and very heavy on imagery that doesn't actually say much at all. The more I read his stuff, the more I suspect he's an utter charlatan, carefully crafting his fiction so that what you're reading appears to be the tip of the iceberg when, in reality, it's a cardboard prop painted blue floating along on the sea, depthless.Writing fiction is a strange beast. In my experience, it feels almost like reverse-dreaming. Instead of sleeping and passively experiencing random imagery from your brain, you are drawing that imagery from your brain and putting it down in order to augment whatever story you're planning on telling. You're actively sorting through your own lived experience and pulling pieces from your subconscious to shape your story and your characters in a compelling, genuine manner. Murakami does this exceptionally well. He's completely honest with himself, and the imagery which seems to fascinate him is often quite enchanting. Often times the quirks he's depicting are enough to carry the scene, alone, and his workmanlike prose facilitates this perfectly by getting out of the way and letting the images take center stage.But there's just not much else there. Murakami is a poor storyteller. His characters are frequently flat and seem to make arbitrary, nonsensical decisions. Many of his novels feature contrived conflict that isn't really all that interesting, or (as is the case in Kafka), no conflict at all. His pacing is often too blown out because he needs to give himself such space to indulge in these episodes of wading into the odd imagery and scenarios he finds so fascinating. Furtherâ€”and perhaps most egregiousâ€”at times he treats his fiction as if it's little more than an avenue from which to explore his fetishistic interests; eg. young girls' breasts, or being masturbated by your sister. If you're hitting me with your kinks, you better be saying something important with them. If you're not using them as a means to a storytelling end that's going to make your fiction more thematically impactful, then you're just engaging in literary masturbation. It's leaving me feeling dirty, like the writer is pulling a Louis C.K. and sitting in the corner jacking off and I'm standing there in the locked room, forced to watch.The more I read Murakami, the more it feels like his fiction is just a vehicle from which he imparts ideas he finds interesting. That's not a problem, really. The best writers also do thisâ€”George R.R. Martin cannot stop depicting romantic hearts stuck in cynical worlds, Ernest Hemingway is utterly entranced with the idea of death and how each mortal person and beast faces it, James Joyce is obsessed with Catholicism and Irish politics. What Murakami lacks, though, and what's so severely damaging to his work, is that there's no storytelling foundation on which all of this imagery might sit, rendering such imagery ultimately meaningless. Martin's characters are so human you'll swear they're standing right next to you, Hemingway's devastating plotting will break you for a full week, Joyce's prose and humor will make you feel the love and the passion of his characters' so deeply your chest cavity will burn with their fervor. Murakami, however, only has his imagery and not much else. His books are a set of really nice windows and skylights sitting on a lawn, with no house into which they might be installed. While they might have augmented a proper story enough to propel it into the realm of profundity, they have zero utility. Yeah, those are some great windows, but who the hell needs just a window? Alone, they're useless. Just like Murakami's imagery.Kafka on the Shore is a nonsensical story with vast pretentions of grandeur. Murakami gives us two empty vessels to follow; an angsty, horny teenager and a developmentally disabled old man. The teenager reads as if he's written to be intelligent and interesting, though I found him mostly petulant and boring. The old man was the more likable of the two, and his quirk was something I found endearing and interesting, but ultimately not much is done with it. The real problem is that neither of these characters have any concrete conflict driving them forward. There's very little forcing them to change, and so we meander through the plot with them, never fully invested in their struggles, never fully caring about who they are. Murakami hits you with some shit, sureâ€”an incest fetish, some shocking depictions of violence against animals, and various bits of nonsense I find impossible to take seriously (building a magic flute, oh my!)â€”but without a concrete story to carry it along, it all felt meaningless and silly, like a Jackson Pollock, except it's just random house paint spilled on a driveway rather than something constructed on an actual canvas.If you enjoy the surreal and aren't a big stickler for, you know, actual storytelling? Maybe you'll like this book. I hated it and I'm eager to move on from it to something else.

I generally liked reading this. The tone is so straightforward, casual, goodnatured, stable, melancholic, with plenty of dramatization and long stretches of easy dialogue. At times it feels like young adult writing, albeit with regular instances of surprisingly descriptive sex, including non-consensual dream intercourse with someone who may be one's sister. The main ingredients include fantasy, detective story, ghost story, erotica, realism. Mentions common brands on one page and fantastic elements on the next, such as a talking cat or a stone that relates to parallel world where life and death and the past and present intertwine, inhabited by two WWII deserters and a woman with porcelain skin and a Mont Blanc pen who may or may not be the mother of the narrator of the sections in first person (it alternates between first and third), at times fifty years old, other times fifteen. Early on there are some official governmental-type interviews about a mysterious aerial event that knocked a bunch of children out, including the illiterate star of the third-person sections. I am otherwise incapable/unwilling to summarize everything in this. â€œIt has a persistent, inward-moving spirit thatâ€™s filled with a pliant, youthful sort of curiosity.â€ Thatâ€™s a line on page 329 about a Haydn piece that seemed self-referential, the only page I dogeared, although every once in a while there was a comment, usually about music, for example Coltrane's solo on My Favorite Things, that directly/obviously related to the novel, which I always like -- as a former English Lit major I suppose I look for those self-referential lines, which come in handy when writing papers in college or GR reviews these days. At times I thought it was shoddy, especially when I read it out loud to my wife upon her request just to read what I was reading and we both agreed the page or so I read was really clunky. I often found myself zoning out, daydreaming, which generously you could say is totally intentional, that Murakami tries to get you back on your heels as a reader, to sort of lower your guard and then once you're lulled/semi-hypnotized, suddenly you realize you've been reading about a ghost woman having sex with a fifteen year old or an old guy who seems sort of touched/special conversing with a cat. I sometimes felt like I had missed transitions or had somehow skipped some pages, the borders between worlds often seeped without me noticing until later, in part because my reading wasn't always super-attentive and immersive -- and again, generously, I feel like this is engineered to a degree and after a while it works its magic. The straightforward superficial aspects of the language, mixed with plentiful musical recommendations like the Archduke Trio and the aforementioned Haydn cello piece, easy dialogue, and well-processed genre melange made for a generally pleasurable reading experience, with enough philosophical and poetic moments/images to qualify as "literary." At first I was disappointed that I wasn't really all that into it but now that I'm done I'll read more Murakami in 2021, definitely, although won't attempt to achieve completism. It's good to know these books and these worlds are available, the way it's good to know that baseball, at least in the summer, is always available when you need it. It seems like it's not trying to do too much on any given page but then when you look back at the sweep of it it's impressive how much it's actually done and how completely it's amounted to its own thing. At first I rated this three stars to reflect my casual kinda disengaged enjoyment but now that I write about the book I've decided to knock my general admiration up to four-star-style respect.

First, the few things I didn't like about the book:1. Everyone talks like a philosopher, regardless of who they are. A truck driver delivers a lecture on capitalism and a prostitute literally delivers a philosophy lecture with a dick in her mouth. The book can sometimes approach self-parody. 2. A couple of chapters felt a little bit too much like wheel-spinning. For example: one of Hoshino's chapters near the end, where he basically just kills time so the rest of the plot can catch up. Now, the many, many things I loved about the book:1. If you want to read a myth that captures modern life, values, love and struggles the way say, a creation myth captured the ancient way of life, it doesn't get better than this book (And you may find that life isn't fundamentally different now than it was then).2. In an age where most stories are interchangeable and nearly-identical and boring, this one blazes with originality.3. You can reread this book a hundred times and still find new meanings and opinions.4. Almost all of the main characters feel like pleasant people that you'd want to hang out with. I especially would love a cup of coffee with Oshima.5. The imagery is as vivid as a painting. The prose has a beautifully poetic flow to it, which shouldn't be surprising considering this is a Murakami book. 6. Despite all the nuance and depth, the book is still structured like a mystery story, which manages to keep you coming back for more. 7. The book packs a huge emotional punch, and by the end you feel exhausted and elated at the same time. If you're reading it properly, it might even help you to get rid of some of your own demons.Conclusion: this isn't a perfect book, but it's certainly a magnificent one.

Warning: all characters are unusual and eccentric. Don't expect anything normal from them.Another wonderful book by Murakami. This book is more into magical realism and metaphysical theorizing as compared to The Windup Bird chronicles and Norwegian Wood - the other books of this author which I've read. Kafka, a 15 year old boy runs away from home, perhaps in search of his mother and sister, who deserted him when he was a mere boy of 4. His father seems cold natured and elusive. He has an imaginary companion, Crow, whose advice he follows in times of internal and external strife. Nakata is a brain damaged man who has the ability to talk with cats. One day he is forced to kill a man, who in turn is a cat torturer. Nakata is in search of something, which he himself doesn;t realize fully. He meets Hoshima, a truck driver, who soon becomes his friend. Meanwhile Kafka meets Oshima and Seiki, managers of a small, private, rural library, who give him place to stay. In the final third, all these characters come together, lots of mysterious and unexplainable things happen, and finally we are left with a sense of wonder and awe, though there is an incomplete feeling.I thoroughly enjoyed the prose, the ideas, the irony and the seemingly impossible events narrated so as to seem almost possible. It is the soothing prose and narrative style, not the story, that matters in Murakami books.

Ever read something that you half got and half was like WTF?This book is so weird but has some great moments, pacing at times is all over the shop and characters arent very likeable. I honestly nearly gave up at the cat killing scene as I found that part particularly disturbing but glad I powered through.I wasnt a fan of the way the book was written with it being about the two characters and how the pacing of the stories was offbeat with each other. Sometimes the Kafka storyline had me hooked waiting to find out what happened next whilst the Nakata story was really slow and vice versa.This is in no way a bad book its just weird and very surreal in places, I hated both the main characters where as in the previous Murakami books I could relate to them in some way these two to me didn't seem human.It might be that I am not in the right place to be able to understand if this book had a deeper meaning or what the author was trying to achieve so maybe I am being harsh on the book. It is one that I will try to re-visit in the future perhaps when I am not under so much stress and try to enjoy the book more. One thing is clear though after reading this I need to take a step back from Murakami for my next few books and come back to him with an open mind in a few weeks time.

Ik wist niet echt wat te verwachten van een boek met een titel als â€œKafka op het strandâ€. Van Murakami las ik enkel al â€œNorwegian Woodâ€ en â€œWith the Beatlesâ€, dus ik dacht dat dit meer van dat ging zijn. Toch is dit een heel ander boek dan die andere. Het â€œmagisch realismeâ€ die doorgaans in Ã©Ã©n adem genoemd wordt met deze auteur, komt hierin toch echt naar boven, en voor mij was dit een heel fijne nieuwe kennismaking. Van de 600+ paginaâ€™s had ik er toch wel meer dan 100 nodig om in het verhaal te komen. Er zijn verschillende verhaallijnen die vrij snel aan bod komen, maar die me aanvankelijk wat in de war brachten. Toch wou ik steeds doorgaan, bleef ik nieuwsgierig en getriggerd, en genoot ik van de schrijfstijl. Ook de vele literaire en culturele verwijzingen waren voor mij een meerwaarde en maakten me enkel meer nieuwsgierig. Hier en daar verloor Murakami me wel even (o.a. bij de pratende katten), maar achteraf gezien hoort dit wel allemaal in dit boek, en heeft alles wel zijn nut, ook al is dit niet meteen duidelijk bij een eerste lezing.Ondanks het volume leest het zeer vlot en weten ook de personages je mee te voeren en te charmeren. Na de laatste pagina moet dit boek toch even bezinken, en heb ik het gevoel dat ik niet alles meeheb wat erin zit. Ooit dus nog eens herlezen, maar eerst nog de andere boeken van deze schrijver ontdekken.

A pleasant and at the same time a confusing read. I don't understand a lot of things in this book, in this story. I don't get the metaphors most of the time. But it was a nice read. For me this book is full of favorite quotes, great thoughts, insights. I have too many favorite quotes from this book that if I try to list them here it will be too long.

Me resulta complicado expresar lo que he sentido al terminar de leer esta novela. Un libro lleno de interrogantes, pero que no importa si no son respondidas, pues el viaje a travÃ©s de la pluma de Murakami valiÃ³ la pena. Es uno de esas historias que simplemente no deseas que termine, necesitas saber mÃ¡s sobre los personajes y de ser posible conocerlos en persona pues calan en lo mÃ¡s profundo de tu corazÃ³n. Creo que necesitarÃ© un poco de tiempo para hacer su merecido video :D. Por lo pronto me quedo con una sola cosa: Este libro merece relectura.

I read this book during quarantine at a time when I really needed to escape. This book gave me that and more. It was a sort of refuge I could find comfort in every night after class. Murakami's extensive imagination, uniqueness and dreamlike quality helped me in so many ways. I can truly day that this was the book that made me understand on a deep level what people meant when they speak of escaping one's problems through literature.

Young boy runs away from home and lives in a library, then the woods (which has a gateway to an alternative reality), while another man (with severe learning difficulties) goes on a mission (with the help of a truck driver) to find a special rock.Oh, and colonel Sanders helps the truck driver find a hooker to give him a blow-job. Finger licking fun!

My favourite Murakami (although I do not claim to have read all his novels). This one features cats, and if anyone ever complies a list of important fiction featuring magical cats, this novel would certainly have to be on it.
I'm annoyed that I finished this so quick, because it would have been a perfect smart-person-airplane-book for when I go to Mexico next week.

Kafka on the Shore is a tale of quests, a retelling of Oedipus, a story of the looping karmic cycle of life and death, and an utterly unique expression of Haruki Murakami's soul.Fifteen-year-old runaway Kafka Tamura has a boss named Oshima at his job in a private library. Oshima tells Kafka:"What you're experiencing now is the motif of many Greek tragedies. Man doesn't choose fate. Fate chooses man. That's the basic worldview of Greek drama. And the sense of tragedyâ€”according to Aristotleâ€”comes, ironically enough, not from the protagonist's weak points but from his good qualities. . . . irony deepens a person, helps them mature. It's the entrance to salvation on a higher plane, to a place where you can find a more universal kind of hope. . . . everything in life is metaphor. People don't usually kill their father and sleep with their mother, right? In other words, we accept irony through a device called metaphor. And through that we grow and become deeper human beings." (199â€“200)And later on, after Kafka sees a girl ghost who is a young version of the older woman who runs the library, he asks Oshima if it's possible that a living person can also exist as a ghost. And Oshima tells Kafka of such a story in The Tale of Genji, followed by this explanation:"The world of the grotesque is the darkness within us. Well before Freud and Jung shined a light on the workings of the subconscious, this correlation between darkness and our subconscious, these two forms of darkness, was obvious to people. It wasn't a metaphor, even. If you trace it back further, it wasn't even a correlation. Until Edison invented the electric light, most of the world was totally covered in darkness. The physical darkness outside and the inner darkness of the soul were mixed together, with no boundary separating the two. They were directly linked." (225)I think it's wonderful that Kafka on the Shore has found an audience of people who are not necessarily versed in Eastern spiritual traditions, shamanism and indigenous wisdom, or string theory. I marvel at the fact that Murakami seems to communicate to people of all kinds. But for me, his work is a modern-day classical expression of all of the former traditions. The literature of indigenous and Eastern traditions is filled with anecdotes of realized beings who often appear in more than one place simultaneously, helpers who drop into our world from other dimensions, people who lose their souls and retrieve them, others who reincarnate within a lifetime, and explanations about karmic packs of people who incarnate to work things out together. String theory (which I don't pretend to understand scientifically, but whose broad concepts make sense to me) with its multiverses (parallel universes) explains such phenomena, delineating connections that are beyond our normal time-space construct.Briefly, Kafka on the Shore is the story of two people's instinct-driven pilgrimages (similar to walkabouts). The main characters are a fifteen-year-old run-away boy who names himself Kafka (Crow in Czech), and an old man named Nakata who became dumb (or "hollow") after a bizarre happening that left him in a coma when he was a child. Also playing important roles are Kafka and Nakata's respective helpers, Oshima and Hoshino. Add to that a delightful cast of subsidiary characters including Johnnie Walker (a cat-killer/famous sculptor), Colonel Sanders who talks about time warps and living in three dimensions versus other ways of living, and a magnificent philosopher prostitute whose casual conversation includes her thoughts on consciousness: "Hegel believed that a person is not merely conscious of self and objects as separate entities, but through the projection of the self via the mediation of the object is volitionally able to gain a deeper understanding of the self. All of which constitutes self-consciousness." (274)The book is a stunning, romantic constructionâ€”a meditation metaphorâ€”weaving the threads of converging, merging, and separating lives from different times and spaces into a fabric of oneness, acceptance, and forgiveness. Both Kafka and Nakata have a dedication to meticulous personal and housekeeping cleanliness, and this same cleanliness characterizes Murakami's style. His clean, simple sentences both seduce and kind of mesmerize youâ€”perhaps explaining why readers who have none of the aforementioned foundation can enjoy and feel the truth of the book without completely understanding it. The style is so simple, yet through the simplicity, Murakami creates the most complex story about the true nature of existence. ". . . there's a spot they call the Toilet Bowl [says Oshima's surfer brother as he conveys Kafka home after his pilgrimage]. There're these huge whirlpools because it's where the incoming and outgoing tides meet and crash into each other. It goes around and around like when you flush a toilet. If you wipe out there, you get pulled underwater and it's harder to float up again. Depending on the waves you might never make it back to the surface. So there you are, underwater, pounded by the waves and there's nothing you can do. Flailing around's not gonna get you anywhere. You'll just use up your energy. You've never been so scared in your life. But unless you get over that fear you'll never be a real surfer. You have to face death, get to really know it, then overcome it. When you're down in that whirlpool you start thinking about all kinds of things. It's like you get to be friends with death, have a heart-to-heart talk with it." (460)[This review also appears on my Notes from a Crusty Seeker blog with an introduction about my personal interest in this subject.]
